text: Text: 'Garbage in, garbage out Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy. But it might not be. In many developed countries, people have their rubbish collected regularly. They put their rubbish bags or bins out, and a special truck takes them away to a landfill. Economists find this strange because it is usually free. Households pay for this service through local taxes, but a family that fills four bins pays the same as an elderly couple that fills one. However, rubbish disposal is not free. The more rubbish people throw away, the more collectors and trucks are needed, and the more local authorities pay in landfill fees. This is a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. The obvious solution is to make households pay for the waste they produce. This would encourage them to throw out less and recycle more, assuming local governments provide recycling points. But as Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, two American economists, found, this approach can have unexpected and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns and cities that started charging households for rubbish. The most common system is to sell stickers or tags for rubbish bags or cans. Only bags with these labels are collected. In a study of Charlottesville, Virginia, a town of about 40,000 people, residents were charged 80 cents for each tagged bag. The number of bags fell by 37%, but this was mainly because people crammed more garbage into each bag, a trick called the 'Seattle stomp'. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14%. In 25 other Virginian cities without a pricing scheme, it fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also resorted to illegal dumping to avoid paying. This is hard to measure, but it might account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. One positive result was a 15% increase in recycling, suggesting people chose to recycle rather than pay for rubbish removal. However, many were already recycling before the fee. In a later study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that pricing does reduce rubbish weight, but not by much. A 10% increase in sticker prices cuts rubbish by only 0.3%. This is lower than in other studies, but not surprising. To reduce rubbish a lot, people would need to buy less of everything. A small tax on rubbish is unlikely to make a big difference. Other factors, like income and education, might be just as important. In richer towns, people throw out more rubbish and have less time for recycling. Should we say charging for rubbish is a bad idea? Not at all. Free disposal is too cheap. But simple policies can have complex effects. Detailed economic models are often needed to understand them, and sometimes the results are not what we expect.'

Theodore Zeldin explores how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Today, just having a successful career is not enough. Many professions feel undervalued, and even famous individuals often feel bitter. Loving your job used to be special, but now you must consider how your work affects you as a person, your mind, character, and relationships. This is important because if your skills make you boring or unable to talk to others outside your field, or if you're too busy to gain wisdom or use your imagination, then no amount of status or money will make up for your lack as a person.

I am exploring how work can focus on fulfilling these personal goals, rather than just shaping us for industrial needs. Work should not only create wealth but also be a meaningful way of life, helping us discover hidden talents and meet diverse people. However, this change doesn't mean ending unemployment. As people become more educated, they want jobs that are interesting and useful. A career should be like a work of art, with a fulfilled person at its center.

Even middle-class jobs are losing their appeal. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients, accountants worry about ethics, architects rarely use their creativity, and administrators are stuck in bureaucracy. Middle managers are losing confidence, and companies are getting smaller. Efforts like decentralizing decisions and rewarding performance haven't gained employee commitment. In Britain, only 8% of employees strongly feel their values match their organization's.

I am studying various jobs to see how they shape or harm people. I've looked at how different cultures expand human potential and create courage. Now, I'm focusing on finding more satisfying ways to work. Many experts work on extending the life and income of companies, but we also need to evaluate ourselves as people and decide who we want to spend our lives with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many are like part-time slaves, stuck in jobs because we see no other choice?

Take hotel workers, for example. They make up 10% of the workforce in the hospitality industry. Many intelligent and lively people work long hours for low pay and prestige because hotels haven't changed much since the days of the Ritz. Hotels are not just places to sleep; they are like mini United Nations where people from all over the world meet but often don't interact. Many hotel staff are foreigners eager to learn new languages and cultures, but they have limited interaction with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers, connecting guests and the city, and using the skills of their staff better. But accountants often limit this by focusing only on profit.

It's time to rethink work from a human perspective, not just a financial one. Work is a relationship. As people seek independence and want to design their own jobs and choose colleagues and customers, they need to communicate beyond professional jargon. True conversation is more than just communication; it creates respect and understanding, allowing people to change through the experience. Every meaningful conversation can change the world a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**

The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds by hand over a large area. This is not just an agricultural term; it also represents the idea of planned growth and success. The metaphor suggests a central source of seeds, or resources, meant to spread and grow. The question is why a new technology that sent words and pictures electronically was organized in a way that fit this metaphor.

Television, like the telegraph and telephone, is a form of communication. However, from the start, it was seen as a central 'mass' medium. Sending broadcasts from a central place to private homes matched the social and economic structures of modern societies. Other ways of organizing television were tried but remained just experiments.

Two lesser-known alternatives show what television could have been in a different social setting. In the early 1930s, radio amateurs in Britain experimented with two-way television as a possible replacement for the telephone. Magazines like Radio News published articles on building TV transmitters and receivers. However, in 1938, the British Radio Manufacturers Association set standards that pushed these grassroots efforts aside.

In the USA, television was mainly a medium for public viewing in the early 1930s and was seen as a competitor to the film industry. In Britain and Germany, most people watched TV in public places. Although the idea of grassroots, two-way television was unlikely to succeed, public viewing systems were operating in several countries in the 1930s. However, the potential threat to home-based TV did not happen. Manufacturers saw the opportunity for mass sales of home TV sets as prices dropped.

As working-class people improved their living standards from the 1920s, the dream of a home filled with entertainment became possible for many in Western countries. This trend is now happening globally. There is a link between social modernization and the structure of broadcasting. As societies became more centralized, traditional communities broke up, leading to new ways of life. People became more mobile and isolated, making central broadcasting a way to reach everyone with important information and create a sense of national community.

Broadcasting became the dominant form of radio and TV because it met the needs of modern societies. It also played a role in democracy by providing equal access to information for political, social, and cultural participation. However, as television changes, the term 'broadcasting' might become outdated, referring only to a specific phase of social modernization.

**Clutter**

Sometimes it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes the desire to get more things goes too far. Modern advertising is made to make us feel insecure. It often tells us that if we don't have certain things, we are not good enough. To see how much you are affected, try not to read any advertising signs next time you walk down the street. These expensive messages influence us in strong ways without us even knowing it. We see them everywhere - on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, the internet, and more - all telling us to buy, buy, buy.

**Caves**

Research centers and universities around the world have spent years studying caves, focusing on their origins, water systems, and life forms. Caves are a small but mysterious part of nature, which makes us curious and eager to learn more. This has led to a lot of research. Caves have been studied for a long time, especially in places where they have affected how people live. However, because visiting many caves requires physical skill, cave research is often done by both scientists and amateurs who explore caves for fun. There is a unique overlap between professional cave studies and amateur explorations.

**Weather Watch**

Many observant people, using only their senses, laid the foundations of meteorology, which has developed since the 17th century into the advanced science we have today. Satellites and electronic tools send us endless weather information quickly, and computers solve complex math problems faster than humans can. Meteorological theory uses long words that are hard for non-professionals to understand. It might seem like there is no room for simple weather knowledge, but that's not true. Human experience is still important for turning computer data into weather forecasts. Human observations can still provide unusual evidence that helps professionals understand the atmosphere.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

Until recently, I believed opera was mainly theatre. Now, I think it's more about music. I worked at a national opera house and learned that music is the priority. This makes sense, but I come from the theatre world, where the spoken word and the actor are most important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once it starts, and the audience usually understands the language spoken.

At musical performances, like concerts or operas, many people, including me, may not have a deep understanding of music. Some might feel embarrassed by this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A talented singer or musician shows the result of years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching a sports event; we see something similar to what we do, but at a much higher level.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often don't understand an actor's skill and aren't as impressed by something that seems close to what they could do. They don't usually admire an actor for delivering a long speech, though they often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are more or less demanding than music audiences; many people attend both. It suggests that in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how challenging the material.

Should music learn from theatre about this relationship? I think so. Music performances are naturally theatrical, full of emotion and drama. However, the way music is presented often highlights the difference between performers and audiences, which can feel hierarchical. For example, strict dress codes and high respect for conductors and soloists emphasize this gap. On the other hand, audiences sometimes interrupt performances by clapping at the wrong times, which can disrupt the flow of the music.

Is there a solution? Yes, much is being done to attract new audiences to concerts and operas and to make 'serious' music more accessible. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from place to place in a cathedral and then into the town. It was a high-quality musical experience that involved the audience directly.

I wish music had more of the risk and boldness that theatre can show. Sometimes, using unusual locations can surprise both performers and audiences. It might be uncomfortable, with poor acoustics or cold temperatures, but theatre audiences have learned to be adventurous. Most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts, but I believe music conventions can and should change.

I am just an enthusiast who loves theatre and music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**

While I admire sand's amazing ability to be turned into useful things like glass and concrete, I am not a big fan of it in its natural form. To me, it is mainly an annoying barrier between a seaside car park and the water. It blows in your face, gets in your sandwiches, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, it sticks to you like glue and cannot be removed, even with a strong water hose. But, strangely, the moment you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk across a clean carpet, it falls off you. For days after, you find piles of it on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and more comes off when you remove your socks. Sand stays with you longer than many illnesses. No, you can keep sand, as far as I am concerned.

**Lock and Key**

The search for a safe home, for privacy and security, has existed since humans first built permanent homes. The simple wooden beam behind the door may have changed to an electronic lock opened by a plastic card with many combinations, but the desire to keep out the 'bad guys' remains. The appeal of a lock and key is partly psychological. Recently, some companies have tried computerized locking systems, where smart cards, swiped through a 'reader', control electronic locks with a digital command. But people don't like them. You might accept it at work, but at home, everyone wants the comfort of turning a physical key in a lock. As a result, when one locksmith company created a new electronic system, they made sure to include a real metal key in the device.

**Modern Art**

I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I can't understand modern art. I know I like some of it, especially furry things, neon light sculptures, and large photographs. Maybe if I knew more about it, I'd have an opinion on more things. Then again, you're not supposed to approach it like a school essay. The point is not to understand art, but to let it speak to you. This is a great idea, but it never worked for me. However, this new gallery tries to give visitors a real understanding of the reasons behind the works. The first thing I noticed were the labels, proper labels that put a work in context and actually told you what it was trying to say. Instead of staring blankly at the pictures as I used to, these pieces of information helped me understand.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

Adapting novels for film often means reducing, condensing, and deleting parts of the story. This can be frustrating for writers but also enlightening. When working on a script, I noticed how much dialogue and description from a novel could be removed while still conveying the same message. This doesn't mean the original text was unnecessary. It's about the different ways stories are told in books and films. In novels, certain details, like character traits or speech tags like "he said," are repeated to help readers understand. In stage drama, which is mostly speech, real conversation is imitated, sometimes to the point where the dialogue seems redundant and only serves to show that people are talking, without clear communication.

**Watching Movies**

Watching movies can transport you into another world, making you forget about reality for a while. Once the film ends and the lights come on, you're back in the real world. In the past, movies were seen as just entertainment, not art. Many people, including our parents and teachers, thought this way. They enjoyed movies but didn't consider them a form of art.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of different buildings, with a confusing layout. There were a few permanent landmarks, like the Script Department, but many rooms looked the same and were hard to find. The studio had three main entrances, all similar, and none had a place to ask for directions. Strangers rarely visited because the studio didn't encourage it. However, employees knew their way around and worked together to create films that offered audiences a break from everyday life.

**Film-makers**

Many people dream of making movies. Bookshops sell guides on scriptwriting and film production, and universities offer courses. Competitions offer cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make El Mariachi, a film that cost $7,000 and made him a famous director. Rodriguez achieved his dream early, making his breakthrough film before turning 25. In the past, filmmakers took time to develop their skills, working as editors, writers, or cinematographers. Directors like John Huston and Fred Zinnemann made their first successful films later in life. Today, without the support of studios, aspiring filmmakers often have to be independent and resourceful.

In those days, the council houses covered the western side of the city: rows of crowded, dull homes in orange half-brick or pale white stucco. In summer, chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, filled the air with a strong smell of sulfur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he walked up to someone's front door. Most of my early life I've forgotten. But I remember sitting, or maybe balancing, near an upstairs window, looking at the houses as they disappeared into the distance. Later, there are other vague memories - faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that I don't think was ours, snow falling over the turrets of the great mansion at Earlham. It's no surprise that my mother appears in these early memories. I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman, whose anger I never understood and couldn't calm. Even as a child, when I went with her to the small shops in Bunnett Square or on longer trips into the city, I sensed her unusual personality. She was the most solitary person I have ever known, as alone in a room full of people as on a moor. She also had a strict sense of propriety uncommon on the West Earlham estate, which sometimes led to furious cleaning or handwashing and instructions to 'behave properly'. As a moral code, this was beyond my understanding: even now I'm not sure I understand it. Specifically, it meant not walking into neighbors' gardens or damaging their rose bushes; it meant sitting quietly for long periods in the dining room, with your hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked; it meant - oh, many rules and restrictions. Over time, other figures appeared in these strict early scenes. Despite her solitude, my mother had friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who was obsessed with the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who said nothing except to agree with the main speaker, and Mrs. Laband - more lively than the others, and somewhat disapproved of by them. It was only later that I realized how poor their company was; they formed a sad and depressing group, talking about bad legs, the cold weather, and ungrateful children, a category I often felt I belonged to. Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight, made up of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly', was on my shoulders, and that I had to grow up quickly to free myself from it. This was easier said than done. Growing up in West Earlham at this time followed a set pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home and got in your parents' way (I remember boring days, when I was about four, playing on a rug in the front room while my mother sat coldly in an armchair). Then, the September after your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile away towards the city. The lucky few had a mother with a rickety bike and a child seat - these were strange contraptions made of cast-iron with makeshift safety straps. As far as I remember, my mother left me in the care of other children in the street for this journey. If I remember anything about these early years, it's the summer holidays, those days when you occasionally saw the world outside West Earlham: an old man who lived next to Mrs. Buddery and told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy; a charity event once, at a house far away on Christchurch Road, where a kind woman gave out lemonade and tried to interest me in something called the League of Pity - a kind of junior charity, I think - only for my mother to dismiss it, saying its organizers were 'only after your money'. My mother often talked about people having selfish motives, and she had a deep distrust of politicians. If she thought of the House of Commons - and I'm not sure she could imagine such a thing - it was like a rich post office where wealthy people opened letters filled with five-pound notes sent by a gullible public. No doubt I exaggerate. No doubt I overlook her good qualities and focus on her weaknesses. But there was little kindness in my mother; it had all been taken from her. To be fair, my mother wasn't unaware of her role in my education. On some Sundays, she would take me - in my 'good clothes' - on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. Here, hand-in-hand, cautious but aware of the free entry, we would walk through rooms of paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother wasn't completely against this activity, and she almost developed opinions on the different subjects. I remember her stopping once in front of a painting of a Roman soldier in full battle gear to say, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' I recall this as the only time my mother tried to make a joke.

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. The evening was getting darker, and the air was thick with a light, prickly rain. This side of the street was familiar to me since childhood. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first friends, all girls, lived in the Kring's and the Pottses' houses. Each house was unique to me, just like the small channels in the sidewalk that carried rainwater to the street. As the street went downhill, the houses seemed to become less grand, with lower porches and smaller front yards. Over time, changes occurred: wooden porch railings were replaced with wrought iron in a Southern or Spanish style. In Shillington, some houses became stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how people lived in these spaces that used to be shops.

**Bachelor Fads**

Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has typical loft features like exposed brickwork and large doors. However, Gilbert didn't want an open-plan space because it was hard to separate work from home life. He used a large sheet of corrugated plastic to divide the space, creating a hallway and leading the eye to the kitchen. He wanted the kitchen to be a neutral area for both cooking and meeting clients. To balance the modern look of the plastic and steel, he used light wood for the floors and filled the flat with sentimental furniture from his parents and markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin's life was full of secrets and stories, making him a unique writer. His first book, "In Patagonia," published in 1977, changed travel writing. It combined imagination, excitement, and deep insight. Chatwin often mixed fact with fiction to make his stories more interesting. He believed that through travel, one could discover histories that seemed to exist just to inspire future explorers.

**Swimming**

During a heavy summer rain in 1996, I swam in the pool behind my house. The rain created small fountains on the water's surface. As the storm grew stronger, the pool seemed to rise to meet the sky. It was then that I thought of swimming across Britain, following the rain to the sea. I wanted to escape the routine of swimming laps and explore the wild, mysterious parts of the world. Swimming, like walking and cycling, allows us to break free from the official version of things and rediscover what is old and wild.

Text: 'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that humans cry for no clear evolutionary reason. He was probably wrong. More recently, scientists have noted its social importance. Psychiatrist John Bowlby emphasized crying's role in forming the bond between mother and child. Many think that tears, especially in children, show helplessness. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying seems less important than the visual signal it sends. In early human groups, crying might have helped build trust and social connections. Tears can also have other reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for those facing great injustice. Additionally, tears can come unexpectedly, sometimes to our embarrassment, when we hear inspiring music or speeches. We might cry during a sentimental movie, but interestingly, this happens more often when we are with others than when we are alone. The social role of crying seems clear, but research is ongoing.'

**The Heat is On**

We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it affect us? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but its exact consequences are unclear. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on our planet, changes in climate will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans rely on these natural resources to produce food, build cities, and support billions of people. Any changes to these resources are important.

The problem is understanding how the world will change and what causes these changes. Over the last 100 years, human activities have increased the levels of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the global climate, but we don't fully understand the global heat balance, making future predictions uncertain. We do know that greenhouse gas levels have changed with global temperatures over the past 40,000 years, suggesting a strong connection.

Research shows that the Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C over the past century. Most scientists believe this warming is not natural and is partly due to human pollution. Scientists use computer models called general circulation models (GCMs) to predict future climate conditions. These models use physics and chemistry to analyze temperature, pressure, solar radiation, and other factors. However, they are simplifications and have limitations. Despite these challenges, most agree that climate change will happen faster than before.

GCMs predict that by 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels will rise by 15-95 cm, and precipitation patterns will change. Extreme weather like heatwaves, floods, and droughts may become more common. These changes could affect ecosystems, such as forests and grasslands, and the resources we depend on, like food and water. Some effects might be irreversible and harmful, but not all. Some regions might benefit from climate change. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have increased wheat yields since 1952.

However, many predicted effects of climate warming are negative. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry regions or areas with existing shortages. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where rainfall patterns have changed. Glacial processes might also change, affecting ice and wildlife habitats. The Arctic ice cover might melt completely, which could help marine transport but increase iceberg risks.

The most dramatic effect of global warming could be rising sea levels, caused by warmer water expanding and melting ice. With half of the world's population living in coastal areas, rising sea levels could lead to severe consequences, like flooding in cities such as London, New York, and Tokyo. Many people could lose their homes, creating environmental refugees. Small island nations might be most affected, as they could disappear entirely, causing devastating impacts on their people and cultures.

Text: 'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day round trip to Mars. Applicants must be physically and emotionally strong. This will be the profile of the first astronauts to go to Mars if multi-millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to launch a capsule on 5 January 2018 are successful. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use Mars's gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, as saving fuel is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next time Mars and Earth are in the right position for a launch is in 2031. It's a big challenge, but the race is on to create systems with new technologies. If these can be ready in time, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it never leaves Earth, the work to reach these goals will still be useful for future missions.'

**Aesthetics**

Sometimes, the very existence of art can make it hard to understand aesthetic theory. This is because art is often seen as just physical objects like buildings, books, paintings, or statues, separate from human experience. However, the true essence of art is what it does to our experience. This misunderstanding can hinder our understanding of art.

Moreover, the perfection and long history of admiration for some art pieces create conventions that block new insights. Once an art piece becomes a classic, it often gets disconnected from the human conditions that created it and the effects it has on people's lives. When art is separated from its origins and its impact on experience, it becomes difficult to understand its broader significance, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explain. Art is often placed in a separate realm, away from other human efforts and achievements.

A key task for anyone writing about the philosophy of fine arts is to reconnect art with everyday experiences. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art should be seen as part of human experience. To understand art, we need to look at the ordinary experiences that we don't usually consider as aesthetic. We must take a detour to understand art theory, focusing on understanding and insight.

For example, we can enjoy flowers without knowing about plants, but to understand them, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight. Similarly, to understand art, we must start with the raw experiences that capture our attention and bring enjoyment.

Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comic strips without considering them as art. When art is confined to museums and galleries, people seek enjoyable experiences in their daily lives. Even those who oppose the museum view of art often share the same misconception that art is separate from ordinary life. The best appreciation of art happens when it is closely connected to everyday experiences.

**Observing Lions**

People often imagine lions hunting as a perfect team. In the evening light, a group of lions quietly moves from the shadows and surrounds their prey. Lions seem to be very social animals, working together for a common goal, like getting their next meal. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to find out why lions hunt together, raise cubs, and scare off rivals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many surviving offspring it has, then working together might not always be beneficial. If an animal is too generous, others might benefit at its expense. So, why do lions cooperate? We thought we could answer this in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. Like the noble gases krypton, argon, and neon, lions are often inactive. It has taken many research methods to learn about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand the answers to our questions.

**Pop Music Review**

The release of Bedrock's third album was a big moment for the band. "New Life" started a movement that changed rock music in the country for the rest of the decade. The old style of serious music with plain clothes and loud guitars was replaced by a lighter, more melodic style. The album mixed social observations and strong emotions with sounds like fairground organs and brass bands. Humor and irony were important, and the singers didn't hide their accents. Bedrock showed they were good at collecting and observing different styles and were clever songwriters. They wrote about traditional English topics like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength was in its gentle, sad songs like "So Low," a beautiful tune about weather, and "To the Brink," a serious ballad. The beauty of "New Life" is its high quality - 16 tracks with no filler, which is rare in the era of long CDs.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I was fascinated by stories of "The Sibyl," wise women who had influence in the ancient world. I first heard about them in a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered Tarquin, King of Rome, nine books for 300 gold pieces. He refused, and she burned three books, offering the remaining six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more books. He bought the last three for the full price. I realized there was a lesson in the story about salesmanship and life. I was sometimes a lonely child. I would ask to play with other children and be refused. My mother told me to do something interesting so others would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson. When I had the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something I wanted to learn about, something relevant to my life. I'm not a big traveler, and I sent my editor a long list of places I didn't want to go. I'm interested in ruins because I like traveling through time in my mind.

**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**

When you submit your manuscript, it will likely join a pile waiting to be sorted. This pile is called the slush pile. The person sorting it is usually a junior editor or an experienced person who works part-time. They don't have much influence, but they want to find something original. The junior editor wants to make a name for themselves, and the experienced person wants to keep their job. If they think your novel is promising, they will pass it to a senior editor. Eventually, it will be discussed at a meeting. The editor will need to justify accepting your novel based on its quality and potential sales. They will also consider if you seem like a long-term author, which you will have assured them of in your letter. Another important factor is how promotable you are, as a new novel needs all the help it can get. Publishers often like to meet a potential author before making an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**

If you worked in an advertising agency in the early 1990s, it might have been a very challenging time for you. The recession was severe, lasting longer and being more intense than expected. In Britain, 1991 was particularly tough: the GDP went down, interest rates stayed high, consumer spending dropped, over half a million people lost their jobs, and many homes were repossessed. Every business was affected, especially the vehicle and building industries, which saw a 30% decline. Many people and companies in different countries suffered.

Advertising professionals were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help improve company profits and were closely watched by their colleagues and bosses. They also had to do more with smaller budgets, being told that "less must be more." Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing was growing. Companies started focusing more on producing what customers wanted rather than just what was convenient for them. This shift increased the status of marketing professionals but also added to their responsibilities.

Marketing was seen as a solution to many problems, and since about half of marketing budgets were spent on advertising, the pressure was on advertising professionals. The 1980s were good for advertising, but the 1990s started with a downturn. This was partly due to the economy, but also because companies began questioning the value of advertising. They wanted to know exactly what they were getting for their money and whether it was worth it.

Client companies wanted better strategies, targeting, creativity, media placement, and thinking from advertising agencies. They wanted the best people working hard to produce excellent work. Advertising professionals faced the same challenge as their clients: doing more with less. This was difficult due to the recession, high production costs, and a reluctance to take risks, which are often necessary for good advertising.

Other challenges included demographic changes, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, the rise of sponsorship, stricter legal restrictions, and the challenge of advertising abroad. These factors forced advertisers to reconsider how effective their advertising was. There was pressure to make sure more of their advertising worked.

Help for improving advertising was not easy to find. Companies and agencies were busy dealing with these challenges and were not eager to share their successful strategies. Conferences and seminars offered some help, but books on advertising often did not. They tended to over-praise advertising work, which was not always of high quality or good value for money. This did not help those responsible for advertising in client companies.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. This was an unusual choice among my friends. Cooking was not a popular job that most of us wanted. Being a chef seemed unattractive: the work is long, stressful, and not well-paid. But these things didn't stop me. I was unhappy at university. The work was hard, and the social life was closed and self-important. Being a chef seemed like the perfect solution to this. It promised seriousness and honesty that I felt was missing in my college life. But my desire to cook was not just because I was a student. It also showed an artistic ideal. I first saw this ideal when I ate a meal at a famous London restaurant. It was amazing. I still remember my starter. I finished that meal wanting to thank the chef who made it. I felt happy for days afterwards. After this, I wanted to learn the secrets of this wonderful art. I changed my student life to prepare for my future in cooking. My history degree felt empty, distracting me from my true path. I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets and delicatessens, and making fancy meals.

**The Swimming Instructor**

The school's swimming instructor was a former drill sergeant, small and muscular, with tattooed arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced that move until the hour was up. The next time, he had me standing upright and diving off the edge. The instructor was strict, and every time I surfaced, he looked at me with disapproval: 'Don't look down, look up!' 'Keep your legs straight.' 'Point your toes, I said!' The next week, I went up onto the high board. It was a fixed board, and its front edge bent slightly downward. It seemed very high as I stood there, trying to gather my courage. Gradually, the echoing voices disappeared, and I felt as if I were in silence. I waved my arms as I had been taught, tried to look up, not down, and jumped into space. For a brief moment, I was flying. When I hit the water, I crumpled awkwardly, and my legs were all over the place. The instructor looked at me with contempt and shook his head. But even he could not lessen my happiness. That's what they mean by 'free as a bird', I thought.

**The Traveller**

For those of us who value a comfortable bed, running water, and the chance of living at least until tomorrow, the idea of the traveller is both confusing and interesting. These are people who choose to risk their lives by climbing dangerous mountains, sailing alone through rough seas, eating insects if necessary, and living for months in the unknown. It is easy to see such people as odd, and indeed they are, like hermits, freefall divers, or writers. They exist, but their strange world is far from our everyday experience and can be ignored, we tell ourselves. We can return to our world of microwave ovens and phones, glad that our only risks are predictable ones like crossing a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, saying it is not his natural place, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He does not claim to be a top sailor, though he is clearly a good one. His main reason for sailing is that, as a writer, he likes to write about his experiences. Sailing provides exciting stories for him to write about. Raban's small boat has an electronic device that gives sailors their exact position anywhere on earth. While he likes this tool, Raban has a simple view of other sailing aids. He thinks the invention of the compass was a mistake, causing a 'break in the relationship between man and sea'. Raban believes that since it was invented, the compass has become the main focus for sailors, so they no longer study the waves and feel the sea. The ocean, once full of life, is now just a space. Since the job is just to stay on course, the helmsman can be replaced by an autopilot for long periods. This may be why Raban had time to look so carefully at the waves.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are closely connected. Books help us feel more at home in the world. We can relate our experiences to those in books from long ago or faraway places because there are fewer human types than there are people. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe situations we thought we were alone in feeling, or express our thoughts with clarity we can't match. What is unclear in us is clearly expressed in books, especially if written by someone from a different place or time. We feel grateful to these authors for reminding us of who we are. Through reading and travel, we escape the dullness of habit. Our eyes are most open during our first days in a new place, or when reading a great book. Books guide us to notice things we ignored before. Our mind becomes aware of new things. We notice the sky, a friend's behavior, or a sadness we didn't know we felt.

**Author's Note**

These travel reflections were published as articles in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have restored some small cuts made by the editor, but added very little. I corrected some mistakes, but only if they were details I should have gotten right. I could have made more improvements, but that process would never end. For example, in the second article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I rewrote the piece to predict this, it would no longer be a report from that moment. Like any traveler, I was there at that moment, not knowing what would happen next, and trying to understand what had already happened. This is the story of mass travel: the world opening up to people who can afford a ticket. But I believe that travelers are not blind. Even a postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

If there were awards for tourism phrases that have been overused, 'ecotourism' would win. The term appeared in the early 1980s, when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized that travelers wanted to believe their trips wouldn't harm the environment. It quickly became a popular marketing term. Now, 'ecotourism' includes anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a one-hour boat trip in Australia. Any tour involving culture, nature, wildlife, or adventure is called ecotourism. The original idea was to help people make informed choices, but the lack of rules left many travelers confused.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my notebook from my Transylvanian journey for 50 years, but found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time and write about it, but it wasn't perfect. In Transylvania, I had an easier time than expected, staying in hospitable country houses for weeks. When I stopped moving, I stopped writing, thinking there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again, and sometimes only took notes instead of writing a full story. I worried that some details might be out of order, so I added warnings. But then I realized this wasn't a guidebook, so I let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**

Fashion is often thought of as a modern idea, linked to the growth of capitalism in the 1800s and 1900s. However, many fashion historians argue that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often start with the rise of markets and trade in the 1500s and 1600s. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new technologies for making different types of clothing have been discovered, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing means. For example, a man's suit, which seems very uniform, can have different meanings in different situations and to different people.

**Writer**

Reports of publishers fighting over new manuscripts have given a false idea of what life is like for most novelists. For those not at the top of the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smartest among us write in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that are secure even if the book doesn't sell well. Others, like me, do various jobs, such as teaching, workshops, and writing articles. I've heard of writing jobs at a chocolate factory, but I've never gotten one. Somehow, by juggling part-time jobs and credit cards, and often with help from friends, the novel gets written.

**Sudden Fame**

The small venues we were playing at around the country started to sell out, and extra security was needed to manage the growing number of excited fans. We had to use secret entrances to avoid being surrounded by fans. On the few nights we weren't working, it was hard to leave the house without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management and others took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, I felt a strange confidence that only shy people in similar situations might understand. In short, I was emotionally overwhelmed.

**Music - The Challenge Ahead**

Technological advances are changing our lives at work, home, and during leisure. Susan Hallam talks about their effect on music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there were more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, videos, and new multimedia methods. However, live music performances and full-time jobs for musicians have decreased. It seems clear that access to music will keep growing because it meets many human needs. National events always include music, and for individuals, it offers many activities, both formal and informal. A society without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn musical instruments.

I believe people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry is a big source of income in Britain, and musical skills will remain important for jobs, especially in media. Besides job importance, playing an instrument may help develop skills early on. Research in the USA suggests that listening to or making music can improve spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. While these results need more proof, other studies in Europe show that group music lessons can improve social relationships in school and help children focus, especially those with behavioral issues. Further research is looking into whether playing an instrument can help develop skills that can be used in other areas. For example, regular practice might help with good study habits and concentration, and playing in concerts might teach punctuality and organization. Because of these reasons, there will likely be a demand for music lessons in the short term.

What about the long term? Will there be a change in focus, and if so, what direction? I think two things might happen. First, the types of music people listen to will become more varied, with new genres mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more in composing and performing music, making it easier for people to compose without needing technical skills. However, this might further reduce the need for live performances and musicians who only perform live. Alongside this trend, more people of all ages might want to participate in making music. These activities will likely be community-based and reflect the community's musical traditions.

If this future is to happen, what should the music profession do to prepare? Instrumental teaching will need to change. More people should be able to learn different instruments throughout their lives. This will affect the music curriculum and how progress is measured, requiring adaptation to stay relevant for more people. Ultimately, it will need to include a wider range of musical skills. Training musicians will be crucial. They must motivate, inspire, and teach learners of all ages, work with large and diverse groups, and gain communication, social, entrepreneurial, and management skills for community work. This is a big change from traditional methods and will require accountability. Positively, it offers a chance for music educators to show the high quality of music teaching available.

Finally, we need to raise the profile of music. Music is important in our lives but is often taken for granted. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**

Actors sometimes face criticism and disrespect. This often happens when they talk about their work in interviews, as required by their film or theatre companies. Instead of using simple explanations like dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it," actors often use clichés or get caught up in gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, once wrote that an actor's work is only alive and interesting when performed. Discussing it makes it seem theoretical and empty. Acting has no strict rules, except maybe being heard clearly. With each new play, actors start fresh, learning and growing with the characters and the writer's insights. When a play ends, actors feel empty until the next project. This emptiness is noticeable when discussing theatre work.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester's performance as Hamlet is a mix of youth and maturity, showing simplicity and confidence. His control over the text and his physical presence make him a standout actor. Lester plays a tense young man with hidden anger, using sharp wit and humor that make him both strong and likable. His performance is skillful, even if understated. Watch how Lester's body seems ready to come alive. Handy's portrayal of Horatio gives a similar impression of being moved by an inner force. This raises questions about acting and behavior: Is acting an imitation or a creation of real behavior? What drives these performances, both morally and physically? This is a key question in theatre.

**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**

This director's rehearsal process starts with "dropping in." The stage manager projects the script on a screen. Actors listen quietly when others speak, noticing the effect of the words. When it's their turn, they look at the screen, understand the first phrase, think about its meaning, wait for the impulse to speak, and then speak. For example, with the line "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" actors breathe, let the thought settle, and visualize a scene, like waiting in line for a concert. They find the impulse to speak, which the director calls "The pathway to the line." Impulses can come from outside or inside. Actors look into each other's eyes and consider their character's situation. The director encourages not to plan or judge in advance, but to trust that something will happen.

**The Perfect Theatre**

The perfect theatre should make you feel your presence matters. Going to the theatre is an event, and the staff should recognize this. It's discouraging if the staff treats it like just another job. The theatre should create a connection between the performer and the audience. Everyone should feel they have a fair view of the actor, not too far away, able to hear and see clearly. The auditorium's size is important; it should suit the human voice and body. If it overwhelms the actors, it's not right. Many late 19th-century theatres got this right, shaping auditoriums that embrace the stage. Theatres with a sense of history, like worn steps in a church, give a feeling of past human presence. You can't please everyone with plays, and you can't predict what the audience will want. When visiting the theatre, you want to see something unexpected, or you might as well stay home.

**Paul Simon and Rock and Roll**

In the 1950s, rock and roll was mainly popular among young people. However, its real importance was the big impact it had on middle-class and older people. It also opened the door for the next generation of rock stars, who listened to it and felt that this new, exciting music would be a big part of their lives. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the main way to hear this new music was through Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was a must-listen for many future rock stars. Like young John Lennon, who listened to Radio Luxembourg in Liverpool, Paul Simon was captivated by the music on Freed's show. He was ready to move from just listening to music to creating his own.

**Snow Adventure**

There was no clear path, but I thought I would be safe if I walked carefully. The wind was strong, pushing me as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow beneath me gave way. I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had formed a thin layer over a gap between two rocks, which I broke through. I climbed out, feeling shaken and worried, thinking about what could have happened if the hole had been deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In an hour, I had only traveled about half a mile. It was clear I needed to change my plan.

**Qualitative Research**

There are many books that try to help researchers with qualitative research. While they talk a lot about collecting data, they often don't explain how to analyze it. Many people find data analysis mysterious. So, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to talk about their methods. The goal was to share insights about data analysis, not to create a guidebook. This means making hidden methods more clear. Although this seems easy, it is actually quite difficult. We let our contributors present their work in different styles, including personal stories and more formal approaches.

**Screen Learning**

A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a TV show he watched recently. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, and he didn't remember much. Many people are excited about learning through the internet and computers, but is learning from a screen really effective? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words carefully, but the son was more interested in playing with the pictures. "If he had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something," the father said. Television, as shown by my son and his noodles, is a medium that gives impressions and suggestions. Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is dialogue with teachers or parents. It needs to be guided. Using new technology to teach children is fine, but formal education still plays a big role.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world's film-making had moved to Hollywood. Local people didn't like it, seeing their area of Los Angeles changed by these newcomers. But in the end, they accepted it because of success, which is important in America. Success in Hollywood means making a lot of money at the box office. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: a film that might make a star, but must make money. In less than a century, Hollywood grew from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. Physically, it has changed a lot: a century ago, you would walk through orange groves to the village store. Yet, in some ways, it is still like a village - small-minded, with limited views - just a part of Los Angeles. For those who live and work there, the main topic is films: how much money they made, who is dating whom, who has been betrayed, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to leave: to work there, but live somewhere else. Yet, it is still the place where almost everyone in show-business eventually goes.

**Photography**

Photography was invented by nineteenth-century artists as a new art form. These artists wanted a lasting and accurate record of what they saw around them, and they found it. The new combination of light, lens, shutter, and a flat surface with light-sensitive chemicals created images that were more lasting, more realistic, and more detailed than what painters could create in weeks or months. This worried other artists; after their initial excitement about the new images, art critics argued that photography was not art. They said that photography was too connected to the real world and that pictures made by machines could not be considered creative works of art. Despite the critics, photographers knew they had found a new art form, a new way to express themselves. They used the new tools like other artists used brushes and pencils - to interpret the world and show their vision of nature and the people in it.

**Book Illustration**

During the time when book illustrations were in black and white, it was common for every children's book to have some form of illustration. This also included many novels for older readers, although this decreased as fewer copies were printed. Children's publishing was still very active, but it was mostly done on a low budget, which led to a lot of routine and average work. However, the best artists always did their best work. The black-and-white archive is a mix of junk and treasure, a great place for research or browsing, where you can find immediate discoveries or start to appreciate a rich artistic period. The real treasures are likely to be shown to the public again, either through reissues of individual titles, new books about the artists, or exhibitions of original books and drawings. There are signs that, after being ignored for a while, this is starting to happen, and the usual process of bringing back old styles is at work. Eventually, a smart publisher will see the potential for a series of classic children's book illustrations from this period, either in reprints or in new editions using the original artwork if it still exists.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**

Some time ago, a website warned about the risks of public check-ins, which are online announcements of where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you're just telling the world, "Hey, I'm here," but you're also letting everyone know you're not at home. This highlighted the growing concern that sharing too much online can have negative effects. The internet offers many chances to share our lives with a global audience, promising things like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the online world, sharing confessions, personal photos, and stories. But soon, we realize that the internet can be dangerous and overwhelming.

This might sound depressing, but don't lose hope. There is guidance from a group of early internet users. In the early days of the web, they explored these challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the ups and downs of being famous online, all before social media existed. These early users, the first bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through now. Before we forget their stories, it's worth learning from them. As the saying goes, those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," as it was called then. The web was mostly used by students, scientists, and a few young people like him. The web was created at CERN, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were drawn to his bold use of this new medium. Hall's rule was simple: if you crossed his path, you might appear on his site, and no topic was off-limits. While some saw him as an exhibitionist, others saw his work as art.

One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video titled "Dark Night." He shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped blogging, but the problem remains. Sharing online is great, but if you expect it to make people like you, you'll be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, including some she had mocked, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect": the feeling that we can say things online that we wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected, and ignoring this can lead to big mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. Though she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and restarted her blog, focusing on her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. Once an example of online mistakes, she has become skilled at sharing her life carefully. Armstrong learned an important lesson: just because the web lets us say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

**Enough Sleep?**

Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and wealthy countries, more people are having trouble sleeping and feeling anxious. In the USA, research shows that 40 million Americans have serious sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books have characters who can't sleep or are set in sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep: how it works, its benefits, and sleep problems. A main concern is that people need more sleep. A top sleep researcher says, "People sleep less when they're busy. They wake up early to avoid traffic."

A sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to settle at about eight-and-a-quarter hours of sleep. This shows they needed more sleep than they were getting.

In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and the dangers of driving when tired. They find volunteers through student newspapers. Volunteers are paid and asked to change their sleep patterns. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures them: "Some worry because we put electrodes on their heads, but we can't see their dreams or thoughts." The lab focuses on physical effects.

In a dark room, there's a driving simulator. Volunteers come at 2 pm, when people naturally feel sleepy, after a short or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road seems endless, the sun is bright, and the air is warm. Many deny they'll fall asleep. Dr. Reyner has a video of one trying not to. At first, he sits upright, eyes open. Then he blinks more and nods off. Each time, he wakes up suddenly, but the car has already veered off the road. Coffee might help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for over half an hour, even with no sleep. She suggests tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum for alertness. Shift workers could use them.

What do we know for sure about sleep? Humans, like other mammals, sleep in a daily cycle. During sleep, we go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. Dreams usually happen in light sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injuries. Beyond this, there are theories. Some say sleep repairs the body, restores muscles, or rests the brain. But these might also happen when awake, so it's unclear. Scientists are sure women sleep half an hour longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they don't know why.

When asked about sleep's purpose, some researchers say, "Sleep helps us pass time safely." Sleep patterns may have been different in the past. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people had different sleep routines. They went to bed at nine or ten, woke up after midnight for an hour, then had a "morning sleep." This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poorest benefited most from this quiet time. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made most people work longer in lit buildings, changing sleep patterns.

Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some non-western places, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, then get up. Continuous sleep isn't possible due to noise, fire watching, and predators. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.

**Simplified Text:**

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots, each costing 800 dollars, standing on rocks in the Arizona desert. I had the full cowboy outfit, but I wasn't a real cowboy. I looked at the Arizona mountains and realized I didn't belong there. I had flown in from Denver early in the morning, thinking I might look like a cowboy. But when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport, I knew I didn't fit in. He wore a sweaty T-shirt, needed a shave, and carried a dirty bag. He looked at my new boots, raised an eyebrow, and left without a word.

I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. I was addicted to driving fast cars, but I don't do it anymore. I wondered what I should do now. A racing driver should have other plans for when they stop racing. I thought I had some, but they didn't work out. I tried to be a commentator for races, but there were too many other ex-drivers doing that. I also tried to sell classic cars, but nobody was buying them that year, so I quit.

Being an "ex" anything is hard. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a World Champion. Even if I had won, people would only listen for a short time. Last year's champion is old news. I don't want sympathy because I had a good career and made money. But I miss racing. I miss the thrill of driving fast cars and the excitement of almost risking my life. I miss the attention from fans and reporters. Now that I don't race, my phone hardly rings, and I have a lot of free time.

I looked at the blue sky and noticed some small birds in a cactus. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I realized I had a lot to learn about life outside racing.

**Vancouver**

In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evenings, residents like to walk down the city streets, and if you join them, you will probably hear a different language every few steps. People come to Vancouver for its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and the mountains, clean and safe environment, and educational and job opportunities. Some people complain about how quickly new buildings have appeared, but there is no doubt that new residents and the growing tourism industry have helped the city grow. Locals used to call Vancouver 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Although the name is not used as much now, Vancouver is more of a gateway than ever.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists like me are usually not good at writing letters. Some say this is because we don't like writing something we won't get paid for, but I don't think we are that focused on money. It's more likely that because we always try to make a big impact in our work, we lose the natural feeling of writing a letter. Real creative artists, who don't think about the effect of their work (even if they rewrite it many times), don't have this problem. I believe that understanding the impact of their words is the true test of a real artist. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about how the mix of long words made them powerful, but it showed he was a great writer.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. You could expect a soap opera star, a radio DJ, or a minor royal to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can open it for free? Last week, waiting pensioners didn't care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were first in line. One customer heard that the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly through the crowd, making those at the front feel proud and those who came later feel envious.

**Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was finally released in 1941, it faced a lot of controversy. The release was delayed because distributors were afraid of what William Randolph Hearst, who was thought to be the subject of the film, might do to them. Despite getting mostly great reviews, the film was not a commercial success at first. It was television that later made it popular again. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the one film that has inspired many people to become filmmakers. This is even more surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles always said that its success came from not knowing what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had an amazing team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper owner who was similar to Hearst, Welles knew he had found the perfect project for himself as both director and actor. He took the opportunity with great energy.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange that morning. He mentioned twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped by the golf club on his way home. He needed to chat with someone, and that was the best place to do it. Twice, Carmel nodded her head in a friendly but distant way, as if she hadn't really heard or understood. "Will you be all right? What are you going to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "Funny you should ask that. I was just thinking I had nothing to do all day, so I was going to walk downtown and look at the shops. I thought it was almost a sinful thing, just wasting the day." Dermot smiled back. "You're allowed to enjoy yourself. And as I said, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't go to any trouble." "No, that's fine," she said.

**Title Race**

Tea boy? No, I'm a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator.

Human nature provides the most entertaining of comedies. A recent study showed that job titles are a major cause of envy and unrest at work. A survey by a top recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees admit that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey found that 70% of office workers would be willing to give up a pay raise for a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title. If our vanity is so strong that it even overcomes basic greed, we are indeed in trouble. The truth is that in these modern times, nobody wants to be seen as a subordinate. The titles being discussed focus on ability (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways to say the same thing.

Text: I was in Vienna to take photographs. Taking photos was more than just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light could change a scene and how one picture could capture the essence of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo, as long as I had film in my camera. I once took a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well that became famous. It was luck, but they say you make your own luck. After that, I became a freelance photographer, but things didn't go as planned. The mid-nineties weren't as successful as I had hoped, even though my photo was on the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which was good enough for me.

I got the Vienna assignment by chance. I had taken photos for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons" featuring London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had just finished the London photos when I was told that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna job. The publishers liked my work and offered me the job. I was free, unlike the other photographers, and I was happy to go because things at home weren't great. A week in snowy Vienna sounded perfect.

They put me up at the Europa hotel in the heart of the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy summer trip, and I didn't take many photos. This time, in cold January, it was different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great pictures. The first day, I just rode the trams around the city, getting a feel for the place. I hadn't seen Schussner's work from other seasons because I wanted this to be my Vienna. A photograph captures a moment, and I was waiting for the right moment.

The next morning, I was out at dawn. Snow had fallen overnight, making Stephansplatz look untouched and empty. I wasn't sure how to capture the cathedral in one shot because its spire was tall, and the base was large. I might have to settle for a partial shot, but it could still be magical. Photography has always had a magical quality, even when you understand how it works. Watching a photo develop is still mysterious. That's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**

Something amazing has happened: London's serious Hayward Gallery has become a place of wonder. This change wasn't due to a big-budget, flashy show, but rather a unique look into a nearly forgotten part of the last 60 years. A new exhibition explores the history of kinetic art, which is art focused on movement, in the twentieth century. It shows that creating artworks that move by themselves or explore the idea of movement has been an ongoing, though often unnoticed, theme in creative work of this century. The exhibition, curated by Guy Brett, who has studied this subject for a long time, includes a wide range of paintings, drawings, documents, and films on kinetic art. These are presented with little text, allowing visitors to enjoy making their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**

Hockney's work attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his art is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers an escape from everyday life. Some people might be more interested in Hockney's charming personality and humor, which makes him popular in the media. Some critics think Hockney is just an overrated minor artist. However, one could argue that he seems minor because being popular is not always accepted today, not because his work lacks depth. Hockney himself knows his limits and believes it's not fair to dismiss his work because it doesn't fit an abstract idea of greatness. He doesn't claim to be a great artist and knows that only the future can truly judge his importance.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**

In recent years, I've seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and some mediocre. What bothers me are shows that push a hidden agenda, suggesting a common attitude among certain artists. Sometimes this works, revealing new trends, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was the opposite of this. With seven artists, I took over a space in an empty warehouse. 'Window-shopping' was a collection of individual artworks connected only by the fact that they were art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a themed exhibition, but why not show them together? They didn't interfere with each other and, through their contrast, added something to each other. I haven't made any big statements about contemporary art, but maybe there aren't any to make about an activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it will spoil their experience. Some say that art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking and the act of creativity. This idea is like thinking that knowing a recipe's ingredients and cooking method takes away from the taste of a dish. Enjoying something doesn't mean we can't also know a lot about it. In fact, knowing more might make it more enjoyable. Pleasure is complex, and how we experience it can be questioned. It is also influenced by history. Our preferences are shaped by the values of the society we live in.
