There's only one way to be the best, and you have to ignore everything else. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. It's either succeed or fail. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, but it also shows the benefits of working as part of a team. My sport lets you excel individually, but it's also a team game, and you have to balance these two parts. It's like life - you can succeed alone, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot - not just money. It has opened doors for me and shown me things around the world that others may never see. But you also have to give up a lot for these benefits.

**Tuning In**

Some experiences are so clear in our memory that they stand out. For me, one such moment happened one night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing beautifully from a hidden spot in a tall tree in the neighborhood. I don't have trouble sleeping - it was the bird's amazing singing that kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I felt like I was in a new artistic world. To follow the bird's patterns, I used my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an amazing, improvised performance. I reacted with groans and cheers as each surprising musical change came through the open window where I lay listening, until I finally fell asleep.

Text: People have always had strong feelings about birds. But what do these feelings say about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. In a greenhouse, a small brown bird, a wren, is hitting the glass. Some people see wrens as mysterious birds that bring messages. Is this wren trying to tell me something, or is it just trapped? Maybe both are true. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed the direction a wren flew could bring good or bad luck. Today, wrens are still popular in British art and homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, wrens are still loved. A forest without wrens feels empty. This is because birds have always been important in our stories and beliefs. In the past, people depended on nature to survive and created stories about animals. These stories can change over time. For example, the red kite was once a common bird in London, seen as helpful. Later, it was seen as a pest and almost disappeared, except in Wales. Now, red kites are protected and have become symbols of conservation in Britain. Our connection with birds goes back to early humans. They watched birds to learn about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about what it means to be human. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and wish for. Some people think our feelings about birds are old and not useful now, but they are still part of us. Birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is sad not only because we lose these birds but also because we lose part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have deep cultural meanings. Their loss is felt by those who know their stories. However, birds without cultural stories are often ignored. Folklore is important. Stories and legends about birds have a strong connection to them, more than scientific terms. These stories bring out feelings and memories buried by modern life. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel is hard to explain with science. Birds are fascinating in ways we don't fully understand, and the stories we tell help us interpret their messages. The wren in the greenhouse connects the present with the past and future, leaving us with a mystery to solve.

**Maps**

A map shows how points and features on the earth's surface relate to each other. This is done using distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in time, like "a day's journey by river." This told more about how easy it was to travel through the area than the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time, sometimes more than maps. Even today, some maps, like those of railway systems, might not show true directions. Early maps used signs to show landmarks, and these signs varied in size to show their importance. The style of these signs depended on the map's purpose and where it was made. So, when studying old maps, it's important to understand the style used.

The history of map-making, or cartography, is about improving how accurately distance and direction are shown and adding more details to maps. Cartography has used other sciences to help. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass. New tools were created to measure angles accurately. As people explored more, they tried to map the world. Astronomers found that the earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flat at the poles, which changed how large areas were mapped.

Over time, different people needed maps for different reasons. Soldiers needed accurate maps for artillery, which led to the invention of contour lines. Archaeologists, historians, and geographers also had their own needs. Modern cartographers now map many things, like geological layers and land use. The value of maps in many sciences has led to a modern revival of cartography.

The development of maps has not always been smooth. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid change. Sometimes, old ideas stayed around even when new ones were available. Cartographers often knew how to improve maps but had to wait for better tools. Since copying old maps was easy and printing them was expensive, publishers were often slow to adopt new ideas. Therefore, maps should not always be seen as accurate evidence of what people knew at the time.

The many maps we have today are the result of much human effort and thought. They are a valuable record for studying human history. This makes the study of historical cartography both fascinating and educational.

**TIM RICE**

I was invited into a young man's drawing room, a calm and cultured space surrounded by a messy cluster of rooms where the less ambitious family members lived. Moving from the kitchen to his parlour felt like upgrading from economy to business class. This room had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across, and surprising evidence that a teenager had spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's answer to the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as crazy; I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams were not life or death to me, though it's easy to say that now. They might have become so if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy ambition for me, to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein, I had no problem giving it a try. This was partly because within ten minutes of meeting, he was at the piano playing three tunes he had composed—I could tell he was good. Very good. As he confidently played selections from some of the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' LP collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I had little to impress him with in return, other than instant praise for his music and a real, actually released, seven-inch single of a song I had written (both words and music) with which an unknown pop group had ended their failing career by recording three months earlier. We parted, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in the charts than in the West End theatre, but told myself on the bus back to my flat that I had just met someone of rare ability and determination, and I would be mad to miss out on being a partner to a guy who was clearly going to take the musical theatre by storm, probably by next week. And even if we failed to challenge the top musical composers, we could try to beat the Beatles and Rolling Stones later, in the summer. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would clearly need some new material. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a lawyer, the brief certainty I had enjoyed of a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded somewhat. I would, of course, continue to keep an eye on the small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a vocalist and would write a few more three-chord songs tailored not to expose the limitations of my voice, but it was still likely that eventually, I would pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would have surely grown out of pop music as my father had confidently predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This was worrying—if he was right, I only had a few more months of enjoying it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to go and see a musical with him, to write words that imitated musical lyricists rather than pop stars. And Andrew was a fascinating individual who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture, besides supporting Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical that he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965 I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was beyond question, and he claimed to have all the contacts. I was soon back in his drawing room. The idea was the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, the nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded the orphanages that bear his name. His story was a worthy one indeed, but not one that truly inspired me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version of his life, and the project was unoriginal in both concept and execution, owing too much to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. On the other hand, Andrew's belief in his score's brilliance was infectious and not totally unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, later to be my agent for over twenty-five years, memorably (and repeatedly) said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there is room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I set to work with great enthusiasm, especially for those songs that were meant to be funny. Andrew outlined the plot, played me the tunes, and in many cases gave me the title as well, most of which had presumably been thought up by his former school friend who had already tried. I skipped a day at the solicitor's office, pretending to be ill, to write my first batch of theatrical lyrics. I did not know it that day, but I had changed careers.

**Language**

Humans have a special ability: we can communicate with each other using language. Language is so important in our lives that it's hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to speak naturally, just like spiders know how to spin webs. Spiders didn't learn web-spinning from a smart spider or need special training; it's something they just do.

**Climate and Weather**

Climate and weather, created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can change the look of landscapes. For example, warm and wet weather all year helps tropical jungles grow, which have many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. Daily weather patterns, which together make up the climate, happen because large masses of air rise and mix. The atmosphere is always moving. Some of this movement is because the earth spins, and the air doesn't move as fast as the earth. The sun is another important reason for air movement.

**Coffee**

As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and, more importantly, make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I spent several days learning how to make coffee, especially how to clean and maintain the espresso machine. I also learned how to make a perfect cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might be moved to simpler tasks. Fortunately, my boss was patient. "Making coffee is both an art and a science," he said, "and you need time to learn how to do it well."

**Art on TV**

Why does television often fail with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be perfect for TV because the camera can show a whole artwork and then zoom in on details. However, there are few TV series that show both the enjoyment and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this problem is Robert Hughes's series, "American Visions." Hughes is a trustworthy critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored by British galleries. I expected the series to focus on great artworks, but instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in its art and architecture.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. Metals markets are less regulated than others. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a big part of the industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. But now, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep the price of scarce metals stable have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is going down. Considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its offshore cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own personality and offers something unique. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If your room doesn't include one, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. Or, you can rent a boat if you want to travel on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to get around here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm, naturally protected waters are also great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. It's not only at sea that you can find treasures. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes of Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay sparkle.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK**

The Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, offers a unique experience: a weekend course where you can build your own custom bamboo bike frame. Located in Hackney Wick, east London, this is the UK's first bamboo bike workshop.

Bamboo is becoming popular in bike construction. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire have brought back this method, first used in 1894. However, buying a ready-made bamboo frame can be expensive, costing around $2,995 or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes affordable for the average cyclist. After years of research, they decided to focus on teaching others to build their own bikes, rather than just selling frames.

The Bamboo Bike Club is more of a community project than a business. James and Ian still work full-time jobs—James in wind turbines and Ian as a civil engineer. Their monthly courses are popular because they offer a custom-designed bike frame and a fun weekend of building at a competitive price.

During the course, participants learn how to choose bamboo for strength and how to make strong joints. The process involves gluing bamboo tubes together to form the bike's frame. Metal parts are used for areas that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. James and Ian guide participants through the process, ensuring quality and helping with any difficult tasks.

Most participants enjoy the hands-on experience of building their own bike. Even if mistakes happen, it's easy to fix them with another piece of bamboo. The second day of the course focuses on wrapping the joints with hemp and epoxy resin to make them strong and durable. After a final waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts.

Bamboo bikes are strong and durable, comparable to metal bikes. Ian has used his bamboo bike for over a year on a 16-mile commute, and James has tested one off-road for three months without any issues. Although bamboo bikes may look a bit rough compared to professional frames, they are unique and have a smooth ride. The cost of building your own bamboo bike at the workshop is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**

Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a manuscript by an unknown psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I took one look at the title and knew it would be a bestseller," she says, laughing, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now a multimillionaire, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book on communication between men and women is a key part of the growing self-help industry. This industry claims to help Americans improve their lives, but it also creates more desires and supports the New York publishing world. In Britain, the genre is also popular, though many books are rejected for being too similar or too specific. Editors focus on marketability, asking questions like, "How promotable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it universal enough?" Dione Reverend says that a catchy title is crucial for success.

**Autobiographies**

There is an unspoken agreement between an autobiographer and the reader that the truth is being told. However, this is often not fully observed. Writers might leave out shameful actions or thoughts, or things they think are not important. Some writers might invent stories to better express the truth about themselves. Others might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is fiction. This can be done without any bad intentions.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Detective stories have been explained as a reflection of the conflicts in late 19th and early 20th-century society. These stories are like allegories. The crime represents human desires like lust or greed, and solving it shows the return to social order. In Hammett's stories, society is restored but shown as corrupt. The detective and the criminal understand each other and are comfortable with each other. The detective is both a crook and a competitor. His mission is sometimes affected by his connection to the criminal world.

**Science Writing**

Stephen Jay Gould is considered today's greatest scientific essayist. To discuss his writing, I met him at the Grand Hotel, where he was promoting his new book. Gould said that understanding the culture is key to being a successful writer. Science is like its own civilization, and only scientists can effectively present it. Gould advises never to write down to the reader. "You can simplify the language but must never simplify the argument. If readers feel patronized, your piece is dead."

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym, a popular spot for City of London workers, the air feels very cold. To handle this summer's high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. At quiet times, it feels as cold as the Arctic. This is an example of how air-conditioning is often overused. It has become important in our lives, showing how we can control or change the climate. However, many buildings could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls that keep out heat during the day and release it at night. These simple ideas can work well and reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are again interested in sundials. Sundials measure time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were important for keeping time accurately. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, they are becoming popular again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks people like them because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm, romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

I used to think china-painting was only for very skilled people. I once saw older women at an arts and crafts show painting teacups with perfect flowers. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners also be talented? But the class was not scary at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups as quickly as I remembered.

**The Wrong Country**

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book, the clerk mentioned that the other people in their package were a school group learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red Your-Kind-of-Holiday uniform. She checked their details and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.

When they landed, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but Keith thought it was just a stopover. It was almost midnight when they arrived at the hotel, and they were too tired to question anything. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. The receptionist told them about the lake and water birds and suggested a steamer trip to Interlaken.

Keith calmly explained there was a mistake; they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, approached them. Dawne asked if she was in charge because they were in the wrong hotel. Mrs. Franks explained that Your-Kind-of-Holiday has many trips, and all tickets and labels look similar. She laughed and said they couldn't end up in a wildlife park by mistake.

Keith insisted they weren't meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they heard typing. Dawne thought Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, remembering everything that happened at the airport and on the plane.

An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, interrupted Keith's thoughts, saying they had the best night's sleep in years. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. Outside, they didn't mention the irony of their situation. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they ended up on a tour with elderly people, when they wanted to escape the demands of the elderly. Uncle had even said so when they tried to convince him to join them.

**He Was a People Person**

American business leaders are now looking at the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports.

In Britain, many people know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose feats went unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are showing great interest in him. Biographies and stories about his ship, the Endurance, are being produced and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a film about Shackleton's life.

Some American managers have started to see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and learn lessons in leadership and communication from his story. They even use the term "speaking Shackleton" among themselves. Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become an example for modern management consultants.

Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has considered Shackleton a role model for years. His company deals with communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises. For example, they handle situations like "this firm's plant blew up" or "half the workforce has to go." MacGregor believes Shackleton is a model for management because of his leadership and communication skills. Shackleton was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of his most important decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole in 1908. This decision showed his credibility for future expeditions because he prioritized the lives of his men.

In a crisis, MacGregor says, people want to know someone is in charge. Unlike some managers today who avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually crushed. Shackleton told his men they would reach safety if they trusted him and did their best. From diaries and accounts, it's clear that Shackleton was always in control. He planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and valued their opinions. He was adaptable and willing to start fresh when needed.

Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. MacGregor notes that in desperate situations, doing nothing can be hard, especially in America, where people want quick solutions. For example, if you buy bonds and the interest rates change, waiting can help you recover your money. Similarly, if a new product isn't working, don't keep selling it.

Shackleton led by example. On the return journey from the Endurance, he noticed the expedition photographer, Hurley, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, insisting he wear them. Someone else remembered Shackleton offering a biscuit when they were starving during the 1905 expedition, showing his selflessness.

Caroline Alexander, author of "Endurance," says the public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton represents the ideals we long for today, standing as a true hero.

**Tapping into a Food Supply**

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae by making holes in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to chisel the wood and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to scoop out the insects.

Although the aye-aye's feeding method was first described over a hundred years ago, scientists have only recently learned how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of two male aye-ayes, Nosferatu and Poe, a female named Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they found insects by looking for signs on the wood's surface, like holes where insects might have entered to lay eggs.

Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with several small holes. Some holes led to cavities with mealworms, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went directly to the cavities with food, showing they didn't need visual clues like surface holes. Dr. Erickson then tested if they used smell or sound to find the insects. The aye-ayes could still find mealworms even when the smell was blocked, and they also found dead, silent mealworms.

If the aye-ayes weren't using sight, smell, or sound, how did they find the insects? Dr. Erickson discovered that they could sense the cavities themselves. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its middle finger and focuses its large ears forward. Dr. Erickson suggests that the aye-aye uses echo-location, listening for echoes from the taps that indicate a hollow space below. It might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting. However, there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also search for insects in wood, so the woodpecker role might not be empty. The aye-aye can be seen as a mix of a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat. It also acts like a squirrel because its teeth grow continuously, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells and using its long finger to get the nut meat.

Text: 'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries give us small glimpses, and family stories are often forgotten. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do it. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they are still two-dimensional. Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a hardback book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if wanted. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary ones. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was disappearing. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "People say they do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it themselves." The promise of privacy helps people to be honest. "I had the confidence to be honest," says a 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune before making another. "I was surprised at what came out. There were painful things, like my divorce." "I did it for my family, so they could learn something, but I haven't let my children read it yet. They were hurt by things in my life, and there are details I don't want them to know now. If they insist, I'll let them. But I'd rather they read it after I'm gone." He also saw patterns from his childhood that led to repeated mistakes. Ms. Renier has noticed this in others too. "It's amazing how many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "Things from childhood affect them for the rest of their lives. They marry people their parents would like or do the opposite to rebel." "Many disappointments come out. Even sixty years later, people regret or resent things with their parents. There is no age of reason. If people had issues in their youth, they still have them in middle age. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed, and some want to say 'I can't stand my mother.'" Ms. Renier is more of a recorder than an investigator. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to be nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should go in.' I include it anyway—they can remove it when they see the draft. But generally, people want to be honest." "It's not vanity publishing. It's not people saying, 'I've had such an interesting life the world needs to know about it.' Things are changing faster than ever, and we are losing touch with the past. It's a way to connect with our ancestors because families don't sit together as much anymore. People want a little immortality." Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, rearranging the order and interpreting. Modern technology allows her to produce everything except the binding with its gold lettering: you can choose your own color and title. Fascinating to the private audience for whom each book is made, the results are not about revealing secrets at any cost. Ms. Renier organizes her material logically and writes well, so the final content is as good as its subject. The book looks high-quality and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost, due to the time involved, deters many people. "I thought it would be a more affordable product," she says. "But the people I've worked with are often from wealthy backgrounds, like readers of Harpers & Queen, where I advertise. They're the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted for their descendants."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**

The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, none of the sculptures here are original. They are all accurate copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with great natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**

Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery showing different photography exhibitions. We often run courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (aged 12 to 16) with our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photographic books, magazines, and a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**

The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from all geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, belonging to Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, showing major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**

This collection has over 400,000 air photographs, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and does photographic work across Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be bought. These are made to order and usually take about a month.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**

The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world and is a unique tourist attraction. Visitors can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By creating resin copies, called facsimiles, the center preserves the originals while allowing people to enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates, used as memorials instead of statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed in revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, with a wide range at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Paternity**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I have had 35 years of small children because of my unusual personal life, and I have loved every minute. I fed the baby this morning, and for me, that is what being a father is all about. I'm very lucky with my children. We all love opera, theatre, books, and music. This creates a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I have become more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical violence. I have slapped my children in anger, but I don't support it. I may not have been a very attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I'm here if they need me, but I let them contact me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, you make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and clothes. This has been very helpful for running the agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy with my business, so I missed some things like their first concerts and sports days. I'm sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising awards with us without feeling shy. I think it's good that I do something they find glamorous and interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if there are facilities for the kids to come with me. This way, they know what I do when I'm not with them, and they don't feel like I'm disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all realizing the need to involve our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about fatherhood. I made big efforts to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next door to each other for a while, so the kids could come and go as they wanted, but I think they found that confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I'm not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I think I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too liberal. I think I could have been more organized. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house, so we thought, "Why keep spending money on new sofas when we could have a kid instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you also become just one more parent in a long line of parents. It's a great equalizer. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at her makes it go away. A baby's smile is the best way to melt a grown man.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's long play about a powerful warrior can feel endless, but in Terry Hands' version, it becomes one of the most exciting shows of the year. He has cut a lot from the text and presents a fast and physical production. Antony Sher is excellent in the main role, performing stunts and capturing the audience's full attention with his intense desire for power. Great performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two couples talk in a sunny garden. The second act shifts location and becomes a deep study of the effects of illness. Wall was a promising talent lost too soon at age 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish playwright, enriches the English stage with his plays set in Wexford. This new play looks at the decline of the fishing industry with strong characters, deep emotions, and humor. It may seem a bit unfocused at times but ends powerfully.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
A classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers trying to kill each other. It's familiar but cleverly done.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

E. **The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century tricksters. First shown in Stratford, it works well on the Barbican's main stage, with great performances by Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after success in Edinburgh. The production is stylish, the acting excellent, and the play is an overlooked classic.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a kind version of Beauty and the Beast set in London suburbia. With music by John Pattison, it celebrates romantic love and is a hit. London producers should take note.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy almost got a bad review, but it is saved by great comic performances from Ron Cook and Anton Lesser. Most others seem uncomfortable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
Another Granville Barker revival, now touring. This play about a lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son is excellent.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He involves her in a web of lies and crime, using her feelings for him and trying to separate her from her friends. Coppard describes her friends well. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes intense. She is trapped in the cellar of an old house, which is described in a gripping way. The book shows details of family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always protectors. A convincing read.

**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious 1915 train accident where eight people died. They work together to understand what happened, using different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts. This clever and complex novel requires close attention.

**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons and takes care of them when he leaves to find work. Despite conflicts with her mother, she manages the pigeons and wins prizes. Set in 1930, this story has a message that there are different kinds of cleverness. Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
Robert Westall tells a chilling story of rural prejudice through the eyes of a mature woman, Rose. She rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage with her two children to escape her materialistic life. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The locals become hostile, putting their lives at risk. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is troubled by her son's ruthlessness. An utterly gripping story.

**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam, from the poorer side of the family, is in awe of his sophisticated cousin Lisa. When Lisa's privileged life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance. Both learn about reality and the value of family. The story is slow in parts but has gentle humor and convincingly shows the growing closeness between the teenagers. It appeals to both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes with humor and vividly describes New Zealand. Robbie, the narrator, takes a job gardening for Stanley. At first, she finds him fascinating, but later repellent. When she discovers what he keeps in his aquarium, the story takes a thrilling turn while exploring character and relationships. Unusual and compelling.

**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
This is a sad story about Mick's troubled personal relationships and difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick improves his self-worth through a role in a school play and with the help of a sensitive teacher. Highly recommended, though it is an emotional read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a regular aircraft. The pilot informed the young passengers that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, similar to the Boeing 707 passenger plane. However, the 13 students from Europe and America who boarded were in for an extraordinary experience. Inside, the plane was a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except for a few at the back, where the nervous students sat. For a year, they competed with other students to join this flight, a challenge by the European Space Agency to propose creative experiments in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a spot on this unique flight, described as an extraordinary roller-coaster ride.

For the next two hours, the Boeing's flight would mimic a giant bird's erratic path, soaring upwards and then diving towards Earth. The goal was to achieve weightlessness at the top of each curve. At 3,000 meters, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane continued to rise due to momentum before gravity pulled it back down. In those few silent seconds between rising and falling, the plane and everything inside became weightless, and the students felt closer to the moon than Earth.

The aircraft took off smoothly, but any illusion of a normal flight vanished when the pilot put the Boeing into a steep 45-degree climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and bodies were scattered across the cabin floor. Then the engines cut out, and weightlessness was almost immediate. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence: the floor felt like a trampoline, and a single step sent us towards the ceiling. We floated aimlessly; directions like left or right, up or down, lost their meaning. Only gravity, by grounding us, allows us to understand movement.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its dive. Gravity's return was less immediate but sudden enough to make some students land with a bump. With the first curve done, some turned green at the thought of 29 more. Thirty curves meant ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to learn how cats always land on their feet. They released the device, and one student managed to turn it belly-down using radio controls. However, another student accidentally landed on it during a rough return to gravity.

Next to the robotic cat, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joins are affected by the lack of gravity, important for future space stations. Another team from Utah State University explored creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They tried to produce these films in microgravity, believing that perfected solar sails could use the sun's radiation like a yacht uses the wind.

After two hours of swinging between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not nausea. This feeling would last a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I already wanted to become an astronaut, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**Jonathon Porritt Talks to Danny Danziger**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.

I had a unique time in my life when I didn't experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand, so I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you can take the time and effort to plant it with trees, then you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice since my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was suitable for planting trees.

I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees sounded nice, and I was eager to start. The rest of the family became enthusiastic as we continued. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres.

In New Zealand in 1968, it was one of those winters with a lot of rain. It rained almost every day we were planting, and I don't think I've ever been wetter or colder for such a long time. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready for the next planting session. Coming out of the Land Rover warm and dry, with the rain falling, and your jacket still damp from the day before, boots still wet, hands struggling with slippery laces.

In the first year, I had someone experienced in tree planting to help me, which was very useful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You have a planting bag around your neck filled with as many trees as possible. When the bag is full, it's difficult, but as it gets lighter, it becomes easier. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide the spacing for the trees, line up three poles across a long distance, and those poles guide your lines. Once in line, you plant all the way down, turn around, and come back.

I enjoy hard physical work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically, getting used to a rhythm and using the fewest spade strokes needed to dig the hole. The rhythm is something everyone talks about, and it's true for many farming jobs. You train your body to do a series of standard moves, and it becomes easy: taking the tree out of the bag, digging a hole, putting it in the ground, stamping it in, and moving on.

Mentally, it's interesting. The brain starts to think about different ideas and reflections about life. Many of my thoughts about the natural world and our place in it began during those days. I've returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is satisfying when you planted them and have a stake in their success. I always worry when I read about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me anxious. However, it turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.

I took a term off from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months alone. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. There's a small cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees, and in the evenings, I did research. The connection between me and that area is still very strong. In many ways, it's the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth.

**BRINGING UP BADGERS**

"What now?" I thought when one of my helpers handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an "open farm" six years ago, and we are known for caring for orphaned animals. The noise from the box—a mix between a cackle and a bark—was unfamiliar. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their coats were like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early life underground. If orphaned, they usually die of starvation and are never found. These three were brought in by builders who accidentally dug into their sett while laying drain pipes. The mother was found dead with her babies still suckling her. The cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing their fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth to mimic the mother licking them. This helped them empty their bowels and bladder. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, the cubs were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though shakily. With each other for company and a heated pad as a substitute "mum," they seemed content. 

Three weeks later, I noticed Willow seemed lethargic, though he was still eating normally. It was a warning sign. I should have acted immediately; the next morning, I found him dead. The vet's post-mortem showed Willow died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, even with antibiotics, in such a small animal. Disheartened by my failure, I continued caring for the others. Six days later, a local farmer who heard about our cubs brought me another male cub, abandoned by its mother. The area had been disturbed too much, and the cub was cold and hungry. Willow II joined us. At six weeks, he was about two weeks younger than the females. Over the next few days, I discovered why his mother left him. He was very difficult to feed. To get him to drink, I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around and squeezing it. After 10 minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn't drunk all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and then anything. Willow was happy to give up the bottle but struggled to eat without walking through his food or sitting in it. Eventually, I offered him a sausage, which he slowly chewed, played with, and finally ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready to try other foods. 

At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and even plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than others that year; the summer was very hot, making it hard to dig for earthworms. By August, my badgers started to become nocturnal and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard; in its long grass, everyone was playful. The cubs would get excited, fluff up their fur like snowballs, and chase each other's tails. As "human badgers," we joined in. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, never did and sometimes reacted colorfully to being caught. During these late-night walks in the dry period, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely extending their territories to find food, as badgers are territorial and will kill others that enter their area. We were warned they might climb into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal to keep it secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so great that we started an appeal to build a sett on the farm for them. With advice, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew up the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate facing their usual walking direction. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for people to see inside from a darkened area. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they forgot about the walks, excited by climbing through the tunnels and arranging bedding. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of the appeal, and local firms donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers with a home of their own. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I returned to find three badgers curled up asleep in their chambers. These days, I don't walk with them as often, especially since they wake up at midnight. We see Primrose occasionally (she joined a neighboring sett), but Bluebell and Willow II still rush to say hello before dashing off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

**In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow the path of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was mapping the 'variations of the compass' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't accurately use their compasses to find their way across the oceans. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time, sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. The first trip was stopped due to problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these journeys, Halley published a map in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This map was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it outdated.

Dr. Clark, who also loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the same route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the journey, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first expedition across Antarctica, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. 'Halley led a remarkable life,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a respected scientist and explorer. He worked in astronomy and geophysics. As Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.'

Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will honor Halley's achievements. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements similar to Halley's, but with more accurate tools. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the international geomagnetic reference field, a model of Earth's magnetic field. 'We usually measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field because you need to know true north for that,' says Dr. Clark. 'We can use global positioning satellites to find true north on our expedition.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean. Ground-based measurements are also useful for comparison.

Halley's Atlantic journey was very important. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian made a naval captain to study declination. Is Dr. Clark ready to make his journey a success? He has spent two years in Antarctica, worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, and sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews. Does he share Halley's passion? 'I'm willing to dedicate eight months of my life to this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't cross the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his amazing life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This display raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: in a world where survival is tough, why do peacocks have such extravagant tails? How do they manage to survive with them?

Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying these peacocks to find answers, a century after Darwin's death. Darwin believed that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the fittest survive and reproduce. However, he thought the peacock's tail was a problem because it seemed useless and even a burden. To explain this, he suggested a different idea called 'sexual selection,' where females choose mates based on beauty.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He believed that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a good reason. The tails might signal some hidden quality that helps survival. Wallace thought the tail was an advertisement for this quality.

Today, the debate continues because studying peafowl behavior is challenging. At Whipsnade, 200 peacocks live like wild birds but are used to humans, providing a unique chance to study them. Petrie and her team have two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the showiest tails? And do these males have other advantages, as Wallace suggested?

Observations show that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which attract more mates. However, it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways. William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy males might be healthier and free of parasites, but this hasn't been tested at Whipsnade yet.

This year, Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and unattractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical.

There's another theory by R.A. Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway.' It suggests that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will inherit the tail, and daughters will inherit the preference for long tails. Over generations, this could lead to the extravagant tails we see today, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on a design change from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. Some might think I'm a romantic dreamer, but I don't think so. My boat uses old boat design magic, but modern technology made it easier to build. However, modern technology often protects sailors from the tough parts of sea life, which they might want to experience. I'm not saying sailors should suffer, but I like my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. Why go sailing if everything is done for you? Sometimes, dealing with the sails is part of the adventure. Also, why move the steering from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot in the middle? This change is often made to create more space inside, like a big cabin. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on water.

When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, for a TV race around Britain, the former owner said it had comfort but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned he was right. Hirta had heavy sails, no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the nicest and easiest boat I've ever sailed. However, old boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I knew I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a good new boat, so I decided to build one. The Westerman has been great. Designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett used computers to help design it, but Irens first drew it on a napkin. He then made a model, like in the old days. We looked at the model and made changes on the computer. The final design was perfect. The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, sails smoothly, and her inside, made from old pitch pine, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed as a sailing boat first, not based on furniture. This traditional method works well. She shows that you don't need to follow trends to be happy and that history can teach us valuable lessons. Made from wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. She has all the benefits of a modern boat but looks, feels, and sails like a classic one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are doing very well. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined body conditioning classes like stretch and tone, yoga, and body alignment. The instructors are very skilled. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, such as aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The one-hour facial made me feel like a new person. The staff in the treatment rooms were friendly and professional. The atmosphere is full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow plans to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you prefer to relax, you can read a magazine or walk in the garden. During my stay, my mood and appetite improved. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy. I definitely want to visit again. This is the perfect break for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

The calm and relaxing atmosphere of this stately home was clear from the moment I climbed the large staircase to the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a charming conservatory, and lots of space, so you don't have to talk to anyone if you don't want to. On arrival, everyone gets a medical check, including weight and blood pressure. We were all called patients, which felt strange since I'm healthy. However, I was impressed when a shoulder problem found during the check was immediately shared with the fitness instructor. We worked on it in group workshops and an extra individual session. Each patient gets a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting, but I was hungry enough to get a headache on the second day. My typical daily menu was grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for supper. If you're not fasting or on a light diet, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and nicely presented. You have a massage or water therapy on alternate days. All extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a fine old manor with inviting log fires and a spacious lounge. If you're counting calories, you'll have to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delightful creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool to work off some of the indulgences. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist recommended good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a highly-acclaimed restaurant, offers dishes that are hard to resist. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu; the choice was amazing. The meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice-cream. I went to bed happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden offers fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments to tone and firm the body if you want to use them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's the best because it's the most delicious I've ever tasted. It's the worst because it's a large piece with 360 calories, which is not good if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the fabulous aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils, fell asleep twice during the massage, and had my most refreshing night's sleep in years. The premises are modern and purpose-built, efficiently run, with up-to-date facilities and luxurious bedrooms. There are plenty of therapists and beauty rooms, so it's easy to schedule appointments. A variety of treatments are available, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. Ideally, I would have a break here about once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps. This means that the things that make us different from animals are very recent developments. Our ability to make art and do other uniquely human things must come from a small part of our genes. This is why studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were unique to humans are not. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple languages with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. 

These findings leave us with few absolute differences between humans and animals, except for art. But if art is a unique human trait, it's strange that our ancestors didn't make art for most of the time since they split from chimps. The earliest art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these don't last over time. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings and statues, only appears around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.

If we say that our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from animal creations? Three main differences are often suggested: human art is not useful, it's made for beauty, and it's learned, not instinctive.

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." Human art doesn't help us survive or reproduce, unlike most animal behaviors. For example, birdsong helps birds defend territory or attract mates. By this measure, human art is different.

Second, human art is said to be motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, suggesting they sing for reasons other than pleasure. Again, this makes human art unique.

Third, human art is learned, not instinctive. Different human groups have distinct art styles that are learned, not inherited. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing their species' song. It's like a French baby raised in Japan suddenly singing the French national anthem without learning it.

The role of learning in human art is also seen in how quickly art styles change. Geese honk the same way they did 2,000 years ago, but human art changes rapidly. Even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake the works of two mid-20th-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in a 1957 exhibition in London, and most were sold, which many human artists can't claim.

These ape paintings blur the lines between human art and animal activities. Like human art, they had no practical purpose and were made for the painter's satisfaction. You might argue that human art is different because it's meant to communicate. However, some famous human art was also created for the artist's personal satisfaction.

**An Exciting Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes narrowed from looking into the distance on their journeys into the unknown. These days, you don't find such people in stories, let alone in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's great adventure was leading an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey, in the calm atmosphere of his family home. The team he led included four Britons (one of them the group's medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese (all experts on the area), 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It later turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before, but were long-distance truck drivers: a misunderstanding that could have cost everyone their lives and certainly put the expedition's success at risk.

This mixed group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's least hospitable desert, and Charles Blackmore has written a fascinating account of their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, to prove something. 'I had always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered promotion, but suddenly I felt I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was, outside all that. It was a big risk. Tina, my wife, was very worried that I wouldn't come back as nobody had ever done that route; we went into it blind. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'

Anyone reading his extraordinary account of that crossing will wonder at the use of the word 'kind'. The team suffered terrible hardships: dysentery; extremes of temperature; severe thirst and dehydration; the loss of part of their precious water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at the limits of our own endurance and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we managed to find some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's legendary sandstorms. And we never hit the raw, biting desert cold that would have totally stopped us. That's not to say that we weren't fighting against challenges the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were torture to climb, for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us.

'What drove me on more than anything else was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Neither our budget nor time allowed one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely on our own. 'I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared of my physical ability to do it. I remember day one -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We've got to do it now!" At that moment, I was a very scared man.'

If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've endured so much; you've got so much behind you. We were very thin, but very muscular and strong despite our physical exhaustion. My body was well-toned, and my legs were like pistons. I could walk over anything.'

Midway through the book, Blackmore described lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, thinking of his family. How aware was he of the ordeal it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I have doubts about myself now, I go back to the image of the desert and think, well, we managed to pull that together. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I've done. Yet in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- against that measure, the desert does not compare.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I yearn for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the resolve of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it difficult now to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Susan Harr felt overwhelmed by technology, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and save time. However, Susan realized that technology can be expensive and not always worth the trouble. She started to let her household gadgets go as they stopped working. This made her question if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets.
