When her word processor broke, she left it in the backyard. She found freedom in not being tied to noisy machines and enjoyed taking her time with tasks like sewing. She discovered that some gadgets, like the washing machine, are very useful, but others, like the television, can be replaced with simpler alternatives. By returning to a small black-and-white TV, her family spent more time walking the dog, reading, and talking.

Susan also started sewing by hand after her sewing machine broke. She found it relaxing and satisfying, and it allowed her to listen to the radio or talk with family. She realized that doing things by hand slowed down her life and freed her from the rush of modern life. She even enjoyed washing dishes by hand, which gave her time to daydream.

Now, Susan looks around her house and wonders if she really needs gadgets like the freezer, microwave, or lawnmower. She thinks they could save money by using fewer electric devices.

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt visits him at his workshop in East London. When she arrives, Hurst greets her quickly, showing he is a busy man. His workshop is full of half-made furniture and various planks of wood. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a great reputation. He is always busy with orders, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want quality furniture, Hurst is the person to go to.

Finding a furniture-maker is not difficult, but finding one who makes simple, well-crafted pieces is rare. Hurst believes there are few true cabinet-makers left. He is disappointed by some modern furniture and criticizes mass-produced, low-quality pieces. His quest for perfection and his talent are keys to his success. Hurst is confident in his abilities, saying he has a natural talent for making things. He learned his craft by asking questions and learning on his own.

Most of Hurst's work comes from private clients, and some return for more pieces. He finds it satisfying to furnish entire homes. However, he admits that not all client relationships are smooth. He prefers clients who know what they want. Hurst also praises others when deserved, acknowledging that some are better than him. He criticizes craftsmen who take too long to make one piece and students who try to make fashion statements with their work. For Hurst, furniture should be practical and useful.

Despite his confidence, Hurst is humble about his work. As Joanna leaves, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Text: 'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. It seems clear that sleep has an important role. However, what that role is, is still being discussed. Scientists do not fully agree on why we spend so much time sleeping. There are three main theories. The most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our body's health. It suggests that we sleep to repair any damage done during the day and to restore our body to full strength. Another theory focuses on the learning benefits of sleep. It suggests that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day, and without sleep, learning would not happen. A third theory is about energy, saying that we need sleep to recharge our energy for the next day.'

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and who does not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Most people have their own little habits or interests. It could be a love for entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the press about many topics. Eccentricity is about showing our uniqueness. Inside us, there is often a struggle between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains on the same track, one called individualism and the other conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel like we belong, more than we want to stand out and be different.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often gather together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests, which others might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, is comforting. We all feel a tension between being unique and fitting in. While most of us follow the crowd, we don't like to admit it. We want to show our individuality, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new acquaintance says, "You must take me as you find me."

At any time, we can choose to be more individualistic and show our personality. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said, "When you feel in your gut what you are doing and then pursue it - don't back down and don't give up - then you're going to mystify a lot of folk." But this self-conscious individuality is not eccentricity, at least not at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention, or a society hostess makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. However, if they continue these actions until they become a natural part of them, then they might be considered eccentric.

The key to eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are. True eccentrics are not concerned with public opinion; they are barely aware of it. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, brilliant criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of the world around them and often act in response to it. Some want to make an impression on society, while others want to escape from it, but all are aware of society. The eccentric, however, continues on their own path, regardless.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've been lucky to meet some of the great thinkers in this field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small, frail woman who was central to environmental issues in post-war Europe. She turned her experiences into a powerful philosophy. As a young journalist, she helped me understand the field better than anyone else. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man," despite its old-fashioned title even in 1976, is her most important book to me. It focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It's a passionate call for what we now call 'sustainable human development.' I've read many books since, but none match it.

**B Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can almost hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the colony. This book explains animal communication wonderfully with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to a well-organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with wildlife artist Eric Ennion was inspiring and created a book for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's painting style came from years of watching birds. With just a few lines and colors, he shows how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful. This is the work of a true field naturalist.

**C Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that has influenced me the most. Besides leading me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation, it defined my love for the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was discouraged by setbacks, but reading this book made my world brighter. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty all connected—a world worth saving. Many say humans are the worst species because of the harm we've done. But I think of Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing the world as a family, all connected. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D Bruce Pearson**

I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and had learned to identify birds during holidays. They encouraged me to start sketching birds to help with identification. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. It had beautiful paintings, chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images made me appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as valid as a scientific one. Since art was a stronger subject for me than math or physics, I saw new opportunities opening up.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five top British publishers about how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said:

**Publisher A**

Reviews are very important for publishers. The Book Marketing Council found that more people buy books because of reviews than for any other reason, like advertisements or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually less upset by bad reviews. They believe that any mention, whether good or bad, can help sell books because readers want to decide for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of the book.

**Publisher B**

Publishers and the press both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make a book and its author known. A good review by a trusted person can increase sales, especially if there are several reviews. Fame helps sell books.

**Publisher C**

Reviews are essential for literary publishing. We publish books by authors who are not famous, so we rely on reviews because we don't advertise much. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest opinions. Reviews can help sell books, but they need to be combined with other things like word-of-mouth, support from bookshops, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**

In the US, a review in the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops don't always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to start reading a writer's work. Some poorly reviewed books sell very well, so it's unpredictable. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer's knowledge than the book itself.

**Publisher E**

Publishers and writers want long, positive reviews, but do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn't sell because people felt they didn't need to buy the book after reading the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's the surprise choice of reviewer or the quality of the review that can make people want to buy the book.

Text: 'WEATHERVANE MAKER The making of weathervanes is a very old skill, starting in early Egyptian times. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham's designs are made to fit the specific wishes of his customers. 'This way, I can make a unique, personal item,' he explains. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.' This is very different from the traditional cockerel, which is the most common weathervane design. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick. Friends liked his surprise gift for his wife and started asking him to make weathervanes for them. 'I realized that there are endless ideas for weathervanes,' he says. Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles - she went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he has no regrets about his new path. 'My previous work didn't have an artistic side, but this is exciting and creative,' he says. 'I really enjoy the design part.' Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He works with great detail, always getting the customer's approval for the design before cutting it by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs in stock, as they are as popular as the custom ones. 'It seems people like hand-crafted items,' Graham says. 'They like the chance to get something a little different.' Graham has no plans to expand, as he wants to keep the business a rural craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I get a lot of satisfaction from turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike,' he says. 'For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction,' he explains. 'Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine.' Graham is getting busier, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients worldwide. American and Danish buyers are especially interested. 'Pricing,' he explains, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His most recent request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.'

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans earned him record-breaking amounts of money. Here, he talks about his inspiration and success.

The start of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. Things went wrong when *Life and Limb*, a film he had been working on for months, suddenly failed. He was worried because it had been two years since he last earned money, and this film was his only hope to avoid trouble with his bank manager.

A sensible person in Evans' situation might have looked for a job. He could have returned to being a television executive or started a TV project he had paused. Instead, he made a decision that seemed crazy, even to him. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel.

The idea for the story came from a farrier he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. Its owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. Such people were called 'horse whisperers'. Evans was fascinated. He started researching the topic to write a screenplay, but after *Life and Limb* failed, he decided to write a book instead.

In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he says. "I was watching people, but I felt alone and like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."

By August, he had returned home and written half of the book. The bank manager was pressuring him, and he needed to know if it was worth continuing. He showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and suggested Evans might get $30,000 as an advance. Evans needed more than that to pay off some debt and keep going. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and needed at least two more. $30,000 was not enough. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, the first 200 pages and the summary were sent to seven UK publishers just before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just sense something is happening.'"

What happened next was historic. Within a week, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking advances for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were shocked. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for it. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent there, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief."

The studios agreed to pay this amount, and they each presented their offers to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four major filmmakers called, one after the other, to offer $3 million for an unfinished novel.

Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on the verandah of his home. He said he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been such a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is tough, and I don't want to become an employee of people I like and who have paid me so much. I'd hate to write a draft or two and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we'll bring in someone else.'"

He would be involved, but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new offers to back *Life and Limb*, but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. "I think I would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

Text: 'Young Masters Age is a challenge for Bobby Fischer as he tries to make a comeback. Chess is now more than ever a game for young people. After 20 years away from the game, Bobby Fischer has returned to chess to play against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer's win in the first game was impressive, but as the games continue, it is clear he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in the best shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer himself helped make chess more popular, leading to a new era of professional chess. Now, winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intelligence. The pressure of the game is intense: players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose the game. Now, games are longer and often played without breaks, which benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the world's top ten players, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Much of the game happens off the board, with players preparing before matches. Computers have had a big impact on chess. A small computer can store one million chess games and quickly show games of a future opponent. In a recent match, both players had teams working nonstop to find weaknesses in each other's strategies. The opening moves of a game are now studied in great detail. Being well-prepared in the opening can decide the game. Today, there are more top-level players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for modest prize money worldwide. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. Losing concentration can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the tension. The end of a game often involves a 'time scramble', where players have only seconds to make moves or lose. In these moments, players must act quickly, like athletes. The game becomes a battle of nerves and determination. At the highest level, losing is very painful, while winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to compete the next day. Most chess tournaments last 9-11 days, with games every day, and there is a year-round tournament circuit. World championship matches are even tougher. The 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow was stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10kg in weight. Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his sudden departure from chess in 1972 surprising. But it also made him a legend. If Fischer has returned for money, he will earn a lot. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will become much richer. But if Fischer truly believes he can prove he is still the best, the result could be disappointing.'

**Fame and Fortune: New British Talent**

**A. Nick Grosso**  
Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, is a playwright with three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a film script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as low as £30." Before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "I never thought it would be performed," he admits. "It's set in a car, which I wouldn't do now because of the challenges. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he explains. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very stimulating."

**B. Simon Pegg**  
Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has progressed a lot since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and recently finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor. I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He performed with the comic group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and as I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me imitating him," Simon admits.

**C. Ciaran McMenamin**  
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous as the lead in "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show was well-received, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says. "I can now choose what I do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, his success seems likely. Encouraged by his mother, he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But I decided to pursue it because I was good at it and loved it." Now, he waits for recognition but is thoughtful about fame. "At 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you realize it's not why you act. It's about respect for good work."

**D. Neil Taylor**  
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be big stars when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company talks about a hit, but I have no idea. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to enter the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix." It was perfect timing. "I was often depressed and in bad bands, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E. Stephen Richards**  
Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many prizes and awards. He is well-known on the poetry circuit, giving readings for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that couldn't be a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became disillusioned with education. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored stuffing envelopes at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published a children's book in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because I read a lot as a child." With his poetry praised, moving to novels is brave. "Poetry has a framework, so there's less chance of mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for bad words. My goal is not to produce work without caring about quality."

Text: A. Isabel, the main character in this funny novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she doesn't want to be seen with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romance books and is looking for Mr. Right. She worries that her knobbly knees might ruin her chances. However, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style like an old silent film, with chapter titles like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired'. B. This story is about the start and near-end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of Francis With, a smart but weak child. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. He takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of dime stores, old cars, and the radio. C. In the author's world, it's normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. So, when professor Richard Vaisey falls for a Russian poetess, he talks to his wife's ex. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help for her brother, who is in prison. The author skillfully untangles these issues with humor and insight into relationships, making it a fun and smart read. D. Two pairs of best friends - two women and two men - meet in London in the sixties and stay connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of them, James Hudson, an American businessman, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, with good writing. It's a book where you can really get to know the characters. E. Written by a top American fiction writer, this funny and caring story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty for a mistake and becomes a 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming an odd bachelor surrounded by household mess. The story explores many emotions and focuses on Ian's touching relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It's a warm book with a perfect mix of sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism: A Discussion**

**A.** Volunteer tourism often doesn't contribute much directly to development. Volunteers might help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot to do this work. If this money were given directly to local communities, it could hire more workers than a single volunteer could replace. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often don't have the necessary skills or experience. Many studies question if gap year volunteering is truly about helping others or if it's more about gaining experiences that help in future careers. However, these projects might help volunteers become more ethical and caring in their future lives and careers.

**B.** Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution, and more participation in global issues. It can also create international social networks among regular people. In this way, the benefits for both volunteers and host communities can contribute to the global good. However, if only people from wealthier areas can volunteer, it might only benefit them and not the communities that need help. These volunteers might use the experience to advance their careers, while the host communities gain little.

**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that benefits the volunteer more than the community. It can also be a way for volunteers to gain skills and experience. At its best, it benefits both the volunteers and the communities, allowing for an exchange of skills and knowledge. Importantly, volunteering can increase awareness and commitment to fighting poverty and injustice.

**D.** Volunteer tourism fits with the idea of helping others in small ways. This approach can seem positive, as it avoids big government and business. However, it also avoids the need for democratic government and reduces development to individual acts of charity. Criticism of volunteering is often unfair, as it can be simple and commendable charity. But when volunteer tourism is promoted as sustainable development, it can weaken the discussion about real development needs. It can also distract from understanding global inequalities and poverty.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**

Many of us listen to the radio in the morning and need something to wake us up. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models.

The first model has a 'dual alarm function', but it doesn't work as expected. You can't snooze with the buzzer and then wake up later. The instructions suggest setting two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends, but not everyone needs this. This model is priced similarly to the second one we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a good deal. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We liked the radio quality, but it's quite large, about the size of a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, 'I need space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I also book a wake-up call just in case.'

This model was the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, although the clock on his test model got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with grey numbers on a green background. The snooze bar is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which was confusing when I read the 50-page instruction booklet. The clock has a self-power backup, so you don't have to reset it if the plug is pulled out. We all liked this feature, but setting it up was difficult, though we felt 'cool' once we learned how.

Tom Granger called the model with a built-in lamp 'tacky'. You have to pull the light out of its socket to use it, which made him question its quality. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work; the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The light is hard to position and only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounds like a submarine alarm and made me want to throw it across the room. Surprisingly, this model is the third most popular on the market.

Aimed at young people, with bright colors and a bootlace strap, this model appealed to Tom Granger and me. 'I like it because it stands out,' he said. The traditional controls made it easy to set up without the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm can be off by 20 minutes, either early or late. Paul Bridges found this unacceptable and called it 'fiddly' and 'useless'.

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger because it was 'standard and took up little space'. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found intuitive. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed the buttons correctly. He admitted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I found the tuning crude, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer worked well, getting me out of bed in just two beeps!

Text: 'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small animal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked, making their spines point outwards. This defense works well if the hedgehog has many spines. Some desert hedgehogs have fewer spines because they have evolved to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger and only roll into a ball if they have no other choice. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, either under bushes or in a hole in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do; if the weather is good, some stay awake all year.'

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in sports is challenging for everyone, but women often face extra difficulties. Training and competitions take up a lot of time, leaving little room for a normal life, so sacrifices are necessary. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we talk to some talented British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**

"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land smoothly, but it can be scary. Sometimes you don't feel well, or it's windy and hard to see, but you just keep going. It's difficult to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses and get treated the same - it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**

"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was surprising because I'd never cycled before! I'm well paid as a professional, and cycling has many opportunities for endorsements. However, I know I'm not unattractive, and it worries me that people might think I've succeeded because of my looks, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I focus on cycling right now, rather than earning money. I train at least four hours every day on the bike, plus some stretching exercises, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is a cyclist too, so he understands the time commitment -- it would be impossible otherwise."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**

"Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools offer it. So most don't start until they're 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches usually stay for only a year or so. There's no continuity, so the women's squad is basically disorganized. But it's great fun, and I love being fit, plus there's a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**

"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world -- I didn't know how big it was then! But Britain felt too small, too safe. I was very determined; I hated anyone having control over me. Now I am more tactful. Each walk has been different. The walk across Australia was the worst experience I've ever had in terms of pain. I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours of sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to because my sponsorship money was going to run out after 95 days. Men think that women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is always seen as a higher risk."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**

"Some men have huge egos when they're driving - you see it on motorways. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of knocks! You have to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's very difficult to earn any money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the twenties and have always been seen as unusual. It's great that more and more women are taking up racing every year. For me, the appeal of saloon car racing is aiming for perfection, always trying to complete a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**

"I get up at 5.30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on my sleep. In the evening, I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes! There is a lot of nervous build-up beforehand, and when you're racing, you really push yourself - you don't feel good if you don't. Several times I've asked myself why I do it. The answer is a) I'm happier when I keep fit, b) I'm lazy at heart, and if I didn't make myself do this, I'd really be lazy, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when an event is covered in the press, 90 percent of the article will explain the men's event, and 10 percent will say, 'Oh, by the way, so-and-so won the women's event'. The prize money isn't as good either, of course. But now we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."

**The Day I Drew Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso, one of the most famous artists of the century. At 18 years old, Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He was low on money and found a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, while eating at a restaurant in Cannes harbor, he saw Picasso, who was 78 years old at the time, having lunch with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Picasso was known to be a private person, so Richard was surprised to see him there.

Encouraged by a friend, Richard approached Picasso to ask for his autograph. To his surprise, Picasso agreed and signed Richard's sketchbook. He even added a playful drawing on the page. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, with the help of an American woman who translated for them.

After showing his friend the autograph, Richard was encouraged to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, Richard started sketching Picasso, who made funny faces to make the task difficult. Eventually, Picasso relaxed and allowed Richard to draw him properly. Richard noticed how youthful and intense Picasso's eyes were, despite his age.

When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the portrait. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and then decided to draw Richard in return. In a few quick strokes, Picasso created a playful version of Richard's face. Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso declined, saying Richard already had his signature.

Looking back, Richard feels very lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. It was a memorable experience for him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? We explain the tricks shops use to make you spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**

Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. They often place fruits and vegetables at the store entrance or have displays of house plants to create a fresh image. An in-store bakery might spread the smell of fresh bread throughout the store. The store's colors, like green, can also make things seem fresher. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, doesn't match this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**

Where products are placed in a store is very important for sales, especially in supermarkets. With computerized systems, supermarkets know which areas are most popular with shoppers. They place high-profit items or fast-selling products in these spots. Shelves at eye level are prime locations for products because they sell better. Special offer bins attract bargain hunters. Stores also use 'complementation' by placing related items, like salad dressings near salads, together.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**

Supermarkets often place basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by more expensive items on their way. Similarly, chain stores put popular products far from the entrance, trusting that loyal customers will search for them and see other tempting products along the way.

**D. Less Sells More**

Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, moved away from stacking items high and selling them cheap. Instead, they display fewer items to make them seem exclusive. This strategy is more about good store design than the uniqueness of the clothes.

**E. Tempting Totals**

Food shoppers often focus on the total cost of their shopping rather than individual prices. Supermarkets use this by mixing low-profit staples with high-profit items. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as 'loss leaders.' More often, they buy in bulk to get discounts from manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**

In chain stores, customers buy fewer items and notice individual prices more. Pricing a blouse at $14.99 instead of $15 can make a difference. This pricing also helps reduce theft, as staff must record the sale to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**

Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully plan their lighting. Chain stores aim for natural lighting so clothes look the same as they would in daylight. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to make fresh produce look more appealing.

**H. Walk This Way**

Some chain stores use different carpets to guide shoppers through the store. These paths, called the 'Yellow Brick Road,' lead customers through the store. However, not all shoppers follow these paths. Marks and Spencer, for example, use wood or marble for paths and carpet for sales areas to encourage shoppers to explore.

**I. In-Store Promotion**

When you enter a supermarket, you might see large photos of delicious food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use 'video trolleys' with screens that show ads as you shop. Sensors trigger ads for products near you, like ready-made meals. These trolleys target impulse buyers and can increase sales by about 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, aged 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic, taking 10 days from New York to the Lizard. Chris and Robin teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their book "Sea, Ice and Rock."

In 1979, while working on "Quest for Adventure," Chris contacted Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail, where Chris could teach him climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. After sailing, they anchored, and Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin went ashore to climb. Chris was impressed by Robin's calmness in difficult climbing conditions. When they reached a big drop, Chris showed Robin how to climb down, but Robin preferred to use his own method, which he did safely.

During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a bigger version of their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin's leadership. Although the skipper usually makes all decisions, Robin asked for everyone's opinion. Chris found the sailing part boring and challenging, as he preferred land and wasn't handy with repairs. Robin, however, enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless, as Robin didn't really need his help.

The yacht was crowded with six people on a 32ft boat meant for four. In Greenland, when it was Chris's turn to lead, he found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety while climbing. If Robin had fallen, he could have pulled Chris down too. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was tougher than Chris expected. Robin, not a natural climber, impressed Chris with his determination. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours but had to turn back. Despite worries about the boat, Robin was eager to try climbing again.

The only tension between them happened on the way home. Chris was supposed to take a watch shift at 4 am, but Robin didn't wake him, thinking he could manage alone. Chris felt Robin didn't trust him, but Robin reassured him it was a misunderstanding. By the end of the Greenland expedition, Chris realized that beneath Robin's tough exterior, he was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been with us for a very long time, in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late 20th century, we risk losing this heritage.

**Prehistoric Wild Apples (8,000 BC)**

Humans have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In ancient Britain, people spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and wrinkled, known in Ancient Britain as 'windings'. They were very different from the apples we know today.

**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**

The French learned fruit-growing skills from the Romans, which they developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The dessert apple, Decio, was introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, most Roman apple varieties did not suit the British climate, so Norman varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and develop new apples, and many Western apples come from these varieties.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**

In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, recorded in 1204, was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Its cooking partner was the Costard, sold in Oxford markets from 1296 to the 17th century, giving us the word 'costermonger' for a fruit and vegetable seller. However, apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and created the first modern-style orchard in Kent.

**Settler Treasure (1750)**

By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', was a famous apple planter. Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was seen as a medicine man by the Indians and became a folk hero.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**

Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing from a dead tree's roots. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed 'Delicious, delicious!'. In 1895, it was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples in the world.

**Granny Smith (1850)**

Another famous apple was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. Known as 'Granny Smith', she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit in 1868. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. She said, 'Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish', referring to both the fruit and her convict origins.

**Uniformity (1950)**

Today, apples are grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, not for taste. This uniformity is reducing the variety and gene pool of apples. While UK gardeners have kept many old varieties alive, the US has lost most of its apples from 100 years ago. Consumers are now demanding more variety. We must value and protect natural diversity in apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unusual destinations with unique itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups average 16 people, led by expert guides. This allows you to learn more about the places we visit and connect with local cultures. It's a stimulating experience for all travelers.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various types of transport, often on the same trip. This includes chartered coaches, local buses, trains, expedition vehicles, minibuses, boats, canoes, rafts, camels, light planes, and walking. Each trip adapts to the local terrain.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people ready for new experiences. They come mainly from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are aged 25-55, with about half being couples and the rest solo travelers.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip is unique, so we divide our adventures into 8 categories based on main activities and interests. These categories highlight special aspects of each tour, but many factors contribute to the success of our trips, such as unique places, unusual encounters, and personal involvement.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a strong cultural focus, emphasizing local cultures and historic sites. Destinations include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Short day walks to off-the-beaten-path sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris visit the world's greatest game parks, offering thrilling encounters with animals. In Africa, you can step outside your safari vehicle to explore. Activities include tracking gorillas in Zaire, bush walking in Uganda, climbing Mount Kenya, and canoeing on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, with some offering hotel stays. In Asia and South America, we stay in hotels or lodges for game viewing, like our tiger safari in India.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our trips is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg in the Sahara, the Maya in Mexico, or the Huli in Papua New Guinea. We travel in small groups to promote understanding and minimize cultural impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walks through countryside or village-to-village hiking. Destinations include Spain, Provence, Tuscany, Crete, Corsica, Greece, Morocco, Turkey, Bulgaria, Thailand, Bhutan, Nepal, and Venezuela. Main luggage is transported separately, so you only need a daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer major treks for strong walkers, sometimes at high altitudes. Destinations include the Atlas, Kackar, Himalayas, and Andes. We may stay with locals or camp, with support vehicles or porters.

**Wilderness Experience**

Explore remote wilderness areas like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara Desert. These adventures offer exotic new horizons and unforgettable experiences.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays use local boats, like felucca sailboats in Egypt or gulets in Turkey. We explore islands in Greece, Thailand, and Indonesia, and cruise the Galapagos on a motor yacht.

**Raft and River Journeys**

River journeys range from a few hours to several days, using inflatables or whitewater rafts. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught. Destinations include India, Africa, and the Amazon.

Richard Nerurkar, a top British 10,000-metre runner, visited a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. This camp is located in Nanyuki, near Mount Kenya, and has been his base for winter training for three years. However, he had never trained with Kenyan runners on their home ground until his fourth trip. During this visit, he competed in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. He was invited by Kenya's national team coach after finishing fifth in a World Championship race. Training at high altitude helps produce more red blood cells, improving oxygen capacity, which has benefited many Kenyan runners.

His first race in Africa was an international cross-country race in Nairobi. Out of the 41 runners who finished ahead of him, almost all were Kenyan. Despite this, he felt he had a good race. He believes Kenyan success is not just due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple approach to running, with an effortless style, simple diet, and a love for competition. The key to their success might be their training methods.

At the national team training camp, located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mt Kenya, the facilities are basic. Athletes live with college students in simple dormitories. Their day includes three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the afternoon, covering about 40 kilometers daily. Sundays are easier, with only one 20-kilometer run. Meals are simple, with tea, bread, and boiled eggs for breakfast, and ugali, stew, and vegetables for lunch and dinner. After running, they bathe in streams from Mt Kenya's glaciers.

By the end of his stay, Richard appreciated Kenyan success even more. He realized it is not just about genetics, upbringing, or altitude. The simple lifestyle, tough training, and passion for success might be the real reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**

Advertising is struggling. This isn't just because of the recession. Advertising started to decline in early 1989, before the recession hit hard. The problems with advertising are deeper and affect the whole world. Advertising hasn't kept up with economic changes. Advertisers think about mass markets and mass media, but as more brands and media have appeared, target markets have become smaller. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller audiences, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.

Think about your shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Many of these won't be advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 products in the store. Over a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. For things like cars, you might buy one every three years, and it might be provided by your employer. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even with all the services and products you buy, you probably don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

Compare this to the 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising. The average person buys 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all because of advertising. That's about 4 percent. So, you could say 96 percent of advertising is wasted, but nobody knows which part.

When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about one in 16 (6 percent), so the other 15 (94 percent) seem wasted. You might think you're not affected by advertising, but almost everyone thinks that. The truth is, nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is part of using media for advertising. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so waste can't be avoided.

That doesn't mean advertising isn't effective. Many ads have shown it is. Advertising needs to reach many people to find the right audience, because advertisers can't know in advance who will respond. Media advertising works because it's a cheap way to communicate with many people. However, all waste is unpleasant. With smart targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond, but they can never know exactly who will respond. Even the best direct mail never gets a 100 percent response.

This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every client. This can't happen with media. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media. They could contact people directly. This is true for all types of ads, from personal notices to soft drink commercials. An advertiser who gains one million new customers (2 percent of the adult population) is doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million extra customers. Any campaign that wins over 2 percent of the population is very successful, and that's a small part of the population. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message more precisely than ever before.

Text: 'Charles Clover explores Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has some surprises. One is Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral with 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. Another is the 'autonomous house', Britain's greenest home, designed by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle sewage into garden compost, and heat their house with waste heat from appliances and body heat from their family and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and blends with the town's old buildings. It is in a conservation area and has a solar-powered doorbell. Inside, the house is very quiet due to its super-insulated walls and triple-glazed windows. Visitors must remove their shoes, and the house feels peaceful. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it enters the house. Robert opens ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is very draught-proof. Even the cats have their own air-locked door. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been interested in the environment for a long time. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s. They designed a house that emits no carbon dioxide and does not use mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to protect drinking water. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they avoid using strong detergents. The Vales wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is less harmful to the environment without living in darkness. The house's only medieval feature is its aesthetic: the hall rises the full height of the building. The Vales pay no water bills, and last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. Soon, they will install solar panels to generate more electricity, enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove, rarely used. In winter, the house stays warm because there are no draughts and no heat loss. Robert says that perceived temperature depends on these factors. The house is low-tech, with materials from a builder's merchant and built by local craftsmen, making it cheap to build. Commercial building companies are not interested in this idea.'

Text: 'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational man, even a scientist. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies taken in a garden, he believed they were scientific proof that these tiny creatures really existed. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos admitted they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick challenges a basic idea of photography, that the camera cannot lie. But it can, and always could. Today, we are used to computer software allowing us to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a true age of innocence. From the moment cameras started capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

**Blacksmiths**

Iron has always fascinated people, and those who work with it, blacksmiths, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created the beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The flowing metal designs of French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were also made by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, blacksmiths were almost gone in Britain. Heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used elegant wrought-iron designs. But in the past 10 years, there has been a revival due to more interest in decorative architecture and creative interior design. Still, much of the work seems old-fashioned, with many products labeled as 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. Trendy stores often sell rusty candlesticks with decorations.

Fortunately, there are new options, and upcoming events aim to promote blacksmithing. The first event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says we might be entering a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently. Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld it easily. Dawson says, 'These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves.'

About 250 pieces are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most of the money will go to the makers, but some will support the promotion of good ironwork, says Dawson. His own works include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He describes his style as letting steel bend and flow when hot, like drawing with metal in space.

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher. Susan May, a jeweler, says, 'It's magical because it's soft when hot but becomes rigid when it cools.' Ann Catrin Evans creates door-knockers and handles inspired by horror film castles. One design looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. She loves that steel feels permanent. Iron has given people visual pleasure and a sense of security. It will likely continue to be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.

**THE DAY I STOPPED SMOKING**

I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't really explain how one afternoon I was a heavy smoker, and four hours later I wasn't. It even surprises me. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I hadn't planned to stop and didn't really want to. I didn't like the constant pressure from anti-smoking groups, and I still don't. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick and seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who had healthier lifestyles.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. "I won't be trying to stop myself, it wouldn't be fair," I said. "Since I'm here to write, not to stop, it wouldn't be right to expect your method to work on me." I thought I was being reasonable. After all, I really enjoyed smoking. It gave me real pleasure. I thought the counselor looked at me knowingly. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and most of the afternoon was in a room so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others.

I guess the stop-smoking messages made sense. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of stopping started to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a private feeling, just for me. Could I also conquer the world? In many ways, it was easy. The physical craving for nicotine, like hunger, faded after a minute or two, and I only felt it for four or five days. The one thing I thought would be hardest without cigarettes—my work—wasn't a problem at all. I believed I couldn't meet deadlines without nicotine and would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, spending weekend mornings at home was the hardest part, and it still is. I think smoking was a way to avoid boredom; having a cigarette was an activity. Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each new experience as a non-smoker is a challenge—eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, a theater break. All are key moments when I used to smoke.

Dorothy who? Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but she is not well-known in her own country, says Georgina Ferry. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know who Dorothy Hodgkin is. When I tell them I am writing her biography, only a few recognize her name. Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel Prize, which should make her famous. If someone had the same achievement in literature, they would be a household name. Hodgkin, who died in 1994, was an extraordinary person. Her life shows some of the biggest changes of the 20th century, like the progress of women's education and the global spread of science.

When I started my research, I read some scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin's suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, a close friend and fellow scientist who also opposed nuclear weapons. I went to a bookshop in my town but found no biography of Pauling. I was surprised that Pauling, a very influential chemist and Nobel Prize winner, was not interesting enough for British readers. Even scientists have doubted the value of scientific biographies. Peter Medawar, another Nobel laureate, once said that scientists' lives are often dull to read about. If scientists think this way, it's no wonder publishers and booksellers do too. This is part of the 'two cultures' idea, which says there is a big gap between the arts and sciences. Only the most famous scientists get biographies in bookshops.

It's not true that scientists have less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists avoid media attention to maintain their credibility. A geneticist once told me he didn't want to be quoted or photographed because he didn't want to seem 'self-promoting'. This avoidance gives a wrong impression of science and discourages young people from joining in. Luckily, this is changing. Scientists now appear in public in different ways. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on a TV quiz, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars on TV. These activities help people see scientists as real people.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be scholarly but dull. They often ignored the scientist's personal life. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which was funny and touching. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie are shown with their flaws. Readers are interested in how creative geniuses deal with life's challenges.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. Her major achievements were solving the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She pushed scientific techniques to new limits. She also had three children and was married to a historian who was often away. Her personal life may not be directly related to her work, but we can learn from how she balanced different parts of her life. Her life is interesting to everyone, and her science is important too. Scientific inquiry was her passion, as it is for any successful scientist. Explaining this passion is the hardest part for a scientific biographer. Most readers don't have enough scientific knowledge to understand complex ideas without explanation. Understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a language—it just takes effort. It's sad that educated people, who would be embarrassed not to know a famous literary or artistic figure, often don't know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

Margaret and her special skill

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a 'sixth sense'. She can use a forked hazel rod to find water underground. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband run a well-drilling business. They use machines like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs a forked hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.

Dowsing is the ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground. It is called a 'sixth sense'. There are many ideas about how it works, from physical reasons like magnetism to spiritual ones. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Dowsers might be able to sense these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' water, while others say they can smell it, as smell is a very strong sense.

The Wilkins have been very busy during recent droughts, with a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of Margaret's customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, 'We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time.' Other customers have remote cottages or barns, now used as holiday homes, where it is too expensive to run water pipes over long distances. Some customers are golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret tries to find water 50 to 70 meters deep. 'You can't drill a well where farm or other waste might get into the water. The water we find is in cracks of hard rock, and if we bring it straight up, it should be clean. But in Cornwall, you have to watch out for iron.' Electricity is also needed to run the pump, so the well should be near power supplies.

Margaret starts looking for water by using a map and a pendulum on large areas like golf courses. 'I hold the pendulum still and move it over the map. It swings when there is water below.' After finding likely areas on the map, she walks over the fields with a hazel stick. 'When I'm above water, I feel strange and reel slightly. Then I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill.' She holds the stick with both hands and pulls it slightly to create tension. 'When water is below, the stick rises. It's important to drill exactly where the stick shows. If you drill even a little off, you can miss the water. My husband checks the same area, and we usually agree on where to drill. If we don't agree, we keep looking until we do.'

Margaret Wilkins is not alone in this practice. Many people are interested in this mysterious skill. Margaret calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This might explain why she is so good at finding water. Without this 'sixth sense', how could her family continue their well-drilling business successfully year after year?

**We changed lives for a day!**

Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different? We arranged this for four people - read about their experiences.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, 30, who works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant.

I had never been in a place like it before. It was so dark and noisy, with many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and I wasn't sure I would manage! Being a mother is busy, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but as I was getting used to it, the drinks fell off the tray and spilled everywhere. I was so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!

By opening time at 11:30 am, a queue had already formed outside, and I felt nervous. I was worried about remembering all the orders, but everything was automated. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn't get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say 'Pardon?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was exhausted and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn't believe it when one waitress said it had been a 'quiet' day!

I never realized how tiring waitressing would be. I thought it was a job for shy people, but you need to be friendly and able to handle lots of customers. I'm quite shy, and I don't think I could manage on a busy Saturday night. I wasn't impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich Americans didn't tip me! I was glad to return to my children. It seems easy after waitressing!

**Cindy's Story**

I was nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it too. I was told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. Little did I know! As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I'd have three hours of peace. Wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me to make the beds, clean the house, and do the washing.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble started. They turned the sofa into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming loudly! I decided to be relaxed, thinking they'd get tired. Wrong again. I thought I had stamina, but they beat me! After much persuasion, I got them into bed by 8 pm, but then the fun started! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew it was just a trick to come downstairs and watch TV, but it was exhausting to negotiate with them all evening.

I never realized how tiring it could be to look after two small children. You don't get a second to think about yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Even so, I really enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary, 30, a teacher at a primary school.

On the farm, I get up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a luxury! But I took a long time deciding what to wear. I couldn't turn up in overalls and boots, could I? Looking at about 400 pupils at assembly, I hoped I blended in and didn't stand out as being from the farm.

After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, using workcards graded by difficulty - very different from when I was at school! Then I helped with a nature project - identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was exhausted and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There's so much to do before classes start again.

I attended a staff meeting about reports and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (bliss!) and then a French lesson in the video room. This was fun because all the children wanted to practice on me, which showed my rusty French. Finally, we moved to the school hall for Physical Education. I was drained, but the children seemed to have endless energy.

The hardest part was standing in front of the class and speaking - even for just two minutes, it's daunting. Teachers may get more holidays, but I think I'll stick to farming!

**Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, bright and early, only to find Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's 280-acre farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes! She also makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream, which is sold in shops and restaurants.

I spent most of the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk, squeezing ice-cream into cartons, and sticking on labels. It was hard not to taste the goodies! At lunchtime, it was time to check the sheep. I drove to a field and picked up a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are left for more than 12 hours once they fall, they could die, so they have to be checked every day. What a nightmare it must be in winter!

After feeding the calves, I started the milking. The process took two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year! I found it quite a lonely day. I missed the children - animals don't talk back! The worst part is not being able to get away from work. The cows always have to be milked twice a day, so it's hard to plan any time off. Rosemary will only get about three days' holiday this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is irregular, and I'd hate to depend on the weather.

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who didn't play music, grew up in a rural area of southern Sweden. At 30, he is now a unique trumpet player in the world. His records introduce new music, including concertos by forgotten composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new works. When you meet him, he looks young and is friendly, much like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV feature was made about his work and development, filmed in both the UK and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong's music, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. The gift was a success, and Hakan never stopped playing. His mother found a teacher for him, the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson. Nilsson saw Hakan's natural talent and was passionate about the trumpet. Hardenberger is grateful for having such a teacher from the start. Nilsson was a 'trumpet fanatic' who was always looking for new mouthpieces. Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument with imperfections, and you have to learn to work with them.
