From the beginning, he had the talent to find the right balance with the trumpet. Even as a child, his unique sound was noticeable. Unlike John Wallace, a great British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances. Hakan's parents supported his dream to become a professional trumpet player. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening. Hardenberger knew he played better than others his age, but it was during his first competition at 17 in Paris that he realized he had a special gift for connecting with audiences. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hakan learned the pieces for the first round and advanced to the second. He knew most of the pieces in that round too, but in the final, he faced a difficult concerto. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and realized that even if he didn't play perfectly, people listened to him. Hardenberger's honesty about his work might seem arrogant, but that's not true. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing his gift for communication, believing that trying to explain it might ruin it. The power of music is in its ability to move people.'

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special tale about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is known for its humor and the author's unique vision, combined with deep psychological insight. It is a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about the incident. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, won't explain his actions. Joe recovers physically but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's condition, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels guilty and asks for a meeting, leading to an unusual friendship. The author is skilled at showing how people react to big changes in their lives and captures the mothers' feelings of never doing enough.

C. This book was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. It tells the story of one of the most remote Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The book mixes this story with important moments in Scottish history, imagined in the dreams of the young main character, Thorfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After a recent successful book, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life is a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness. Rosie helps her in her enjoyable manipulation of suitors and friends. By the end, Aurora must face the passage of time and the rise of a new generation. The author is good at showing the sadness beneath ordinary life and focuses on the unexpected nature of events.

E. Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses impressive descriptive language to show each person's journey of self-discovery. They return home with their spirits renewed by their time on the "desert cities of waves." The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both confusing and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and their usual workday.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and start work by 8 am. I begin operating at 8:30 am. I operate all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most head operations take three hours, but some can last all day. I've worked ten hours straight without eating or using the bathroom. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. I don't feel stressed while operating, but I do worry about the next day's plans. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it's amazing and makes up for the times it doesn't. From 10 am to 1 pm, I have an out-patients' clinic where I explain the operations. I enjoy talking to patients, but time pressure can make it hard to comfort them if they get upset. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I'm on call and always carry my pager. On holidays, I worry for the first three days about the patients I've left behind, and I dream about operating at night. I'm not good at relaxing."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I get up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9:15 am. On Monday at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work, any problems, or if anyone needs help. We work in teams; my team has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. The work is about 10-15% design; the rest is production. I get a brief from the client, and if we're lucky, they have clear ideas about their goals, target market, and project form. I spend three to four weeks designing, researching, and developing the project. After presenting my ideas to the client and getting their approval, we work out estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I coordinate with printers to ensure the job's needs are met on time. I spend a lot of time managing people and need to communicate well with a wide range of people. When their work comes in, I assemble everything and send it to the printers. Managing several jobs at once can be very stressful. Deadlines are always near, and no day is the same. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, and we try to go to the pub. Otherwise, I have sandwiches and work through. It's great when the client likes the designs and the project works; it's disappointing when a job gets rejected after hard work. I get home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often at 8:30 pm, and sometimes much later. I find it hard to relax when I get back, especially if I'm very busy."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I get up at about 7 am most days, but two or three mornings a week, I meet a long-haul flight from Heathrow or Gatwick and get up between 4:30 am and 5 am. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Because chauffeuring is a sitting job, I have to watch my diet and exercise carefully. I usually have a big breakfast and just have snacks during the day. People often ask me to recommend restaurants, nightclubs, or shops, so I need to know my way around. Luckily, many jobs are pre-booked, so I can check routes beforehand. Not everyone is polite. Some passengers are unfriendly, some arrogant, some very rude. But most people behave well, and I've built a good relationship with my regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on the road and ignore them. The press has tried to make me talk about clients, but I won't. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I have to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I get up at about 7 am, leave the house at 7:30 am, and get to my first job. My assistant and I spend most of our time maintaining gardens we originally designed and landscaped. We do a few commercial jobs, but most of our work is in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At about 11 am, we get hungry and go to a local cafe for a big breakfast. I often look at my watch and wish it was earlier and that time didn't pass so quickly. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. The business office is at home, so when I get back, I listen to messages and respond to calls. If someone wants their garden landscaped, I'll usually arrange a consultation with them in the evening, around 7 pm or 8 pm. We specialize in using old materials, like old bricks and unusual plants, to make gardens look as if they were built a long time ago. But sometimes people have a set idea of what they want, and it can be pretty horrible. Still, it's very satisfying when we do a complete landscape from start to finish and then see all the blooms come out. It's hard to relax in the evenings because I can always hear the business line when it rings. I never have trouble sleeping because the work is so physical that I'm always exhausted at the end of the day. I wouldn't say I'm very strong, but I'm fit. Physically, it's a very tough job, but it lets your imagination run wild."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I'm the assistant resident engineer at the site, so I look after building a couple of bridges and a retaining wall, which stops people from driving off the road into a quarry. I check that the contractors are working to the schedule and specifications, with correct safety systems and minimum environmental impact. I help coordinate the site professionals and find solutions to any problems. The contractors start work at 6 am, so my first task is to find out from the clerk of works what's been going on since I left the night before. The rest of the day is a reaction to whatever he tells me. Usually, there's some paperwork from the contractors to look at, or there might be design questions to answer. Lunch is usually for half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I tend to grab things to eat as I go along. The contractors have set mealtimes, and when they're off eating, it's easier to check things on site. Because we're checking their work, it can cause conflict, so our relationship has to be as open as possible. I see the duty resident engineer once a day. However, if something really important comes up, I don't wait to tell them before I act. I usually leave the site at about 6 pm, and I'm on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**

I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7.30 am. I manage customer programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then answer emails. I handle all advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with our marketing team and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future developments. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. There are nine customer service units in Europe, and I travel to different markets once or twice a week to discuss issues. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6.30 pm and 7.00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**

I start work at 10.00 am and go through the mail, which includes 10-20 demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices. The phone starts ringing at 10.30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day about campaigns or projects for artists, involving the press, marketing, and the managing director. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be constructive because it's important to the artists. I know if the sound fits our label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing and sales. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work at 7.00 pm at the earliest and often go to gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. After gigs, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life is mostly work-related, and I often get home at 1.00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**

I get up at 8.00 am and drive to work, arriving at 9.30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client visits, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and making sales, knowing the furniture is going to a good home. We sell antiques from £1,000 to £6,000 and buy from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration. We have a full-time restorer, and I work with gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while having coffee to stay updated on the business, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts monthly and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5.30 pm and it takes about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**

I work a set shift pattern, leaving home at 6.00 am for an early shift. At 7.00 am, I take over one of the four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for about an hour and a half, then taking a half-hour break before returning to a different station. The air traffic controllers, supervisor, and watch manager work as a team to control aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing time to read up on new air traffic requirements between 12 and 4.00 am. It's important to be alert in this job, so I don't hesitate to call in sick if I'm unwell. The work is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually a general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**

If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8.00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the till and coordinate staff lunches and breaks. I spend the morning helping customers and ordering books for them. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be annoying when they expect you to gather a pile of books based on reviews. Between 2.00 pm and 4.00 pm, publishers' reps visit the shop, and I discuss new titles for the coming months. I decide how many copies of a title the shop might sell. When featuring a new title, I ensure it's delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5.45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the computer system, locking up, and going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**

I listen to the news at 7.00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving at 8.45 am. I contact our freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies abroad, warning clients of potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9.15 am to 9.30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first executive preview is due online by 10.00 am, and the second by 11.00 am, so I quickly follow up on stories. I type them, send them to my editor for approval, then make any changes before they go through the system. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events or stay updated. I leave work around 6.00 pm. It's hard to switch off, and I'm often awake until 1.00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires and guides others. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, author of "Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace," says leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is important, and a good leader should speak clearly and confidently. Dixon says, "It's having the confidence to say 'I believe' instead of 'I think.'"

B. **Recognizing Leadership Potential**  
John van Maurik, director of a Leadership in Management course, believes many people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader means recognizing and developing these hidden talents. We are all born with leadership abilities; we just need the right situations to grow. While it's easy to see leadership in famous people like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplace. Yet, leadership is essential for effective management.

C. **The Best and Worst Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these? The best leader motivated and supported you. The worst made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first led well; the second managed poorly.

D. **Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like working within set rules. Leaders create new paths. Michael Shea, author of "Leadership Rules," writes, "A good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can transform a struggling organization."

E. **Improving Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you're a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons:  
- Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find what you are passionate about and act on it.  
- Think of yourself as a leader. Recognize your ability to lead.  
- Sometimes firm leadership is needed. Try different styles. If you usually ask for others' opinions, try taking the lead. Notice how this changes the outcome.  
- Set goals and exceed them. Identify areas in your job where leadership can improve your effectiveness and career.

F. **Developing Leadership**  
- Leadership develops by taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and praise.  
- Your way of leading might not win over everyone. Keep improving your communication skills. You don't have to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be.  
- Be visible and accessible to important people. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your contribution is vital and help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made this intense Cold War thriller. It’s about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The characters, especially foreman Bud, remind us of heroes in Howard Hawks' movies. The production design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and characters are not as strong. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, is interesting compared to Terrence Malick's new film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is a more traditional war movie, often closer to the book. It focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Although Malick's film is richer, Marton's has its moments, like the flashback of the soldier dreaming of his wife, which is more intense than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
Loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, this entertaining swashbuckler is better than most musketeer adventures. Fabrice Luchini plays a great villain, a sneaky politician causing chaos. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short. Daniel Auteuil, as an acrobat-turned-swordsman, is perhaps too serious for this fun film, but he has his moments. The filmmakers use costume-drama clichés with such wit and energy that it works well.

**D. Character**  
This is a serious story set in early 1900s Rotterdam. The detailed production and costumes make the film look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is ruthless when evicting tenants. The main story is about his difficult relationship with his son, but the filmmakers focus too much on the period details, missing the dark and intense story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This digitally re-mastered video shows director Leone's skills at their best. The sound editing is excellent, with every sound clear and loud. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's great music makes it exciting again. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), as they all act without scruples in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck features 'forty-eight international stars.' With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, are slow for both the audience and the characters. Logistically, it’s impressive, but it needs a big screen to be fully appreciated. On video, it loses some of its impact.

**BOOK A**  
Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is truly engaging. The story follows a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a big law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife, who is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, with the result uncertain until the end, and there is a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B**  
*Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with excitement and throws Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy, into a mix of politics, church intrigue, and murder. We are sure he will solve the mystery and find the guilty. The plot is complex and the book is a bit long, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C**  
*File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, created by first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah is a tax inspector who starts investigating when a strange man dies at her feet. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a local detective sergeant, Leah is strong and successful in every way.

**BOOK D**  
*Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator, helping his friend Hawk to remove drug dealers from a poor area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and there is more philosophy than usual. As always, Parker provides high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E**  
*False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate an attack and robbery at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and understanding of human behavior make this an entertaining mystery.

**BOOK F**  
Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock, a husband and wife team, wrote *Blood Red, Snow White*. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book mixes romance, money, and violence to create an exciting suspense novel.

**BOOK G**  
*Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher, who becomes a target. A funny group of characters gathers to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels this is not the right direction for his career. While Shaw usually entertains, this book is not as strong as his others.

**BOOK H**  
*Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are after a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow, well-paced build-up of tension and the portrayal of the smart, troubled robber make this a standout detective novel.

Text: 'I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age decide to take this big step. This summer, I quit my job, decided to rent out my apartment, and travel in Southeast Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old, and I'm nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking around North and South America, and when I came back, I was determined to do it again someday. But you know how it is... I fell in love, started a career, bought an apartment, and got used to earning a salary. But I slowly realized I was giving up my own happiness for my salary. When I handed in my resignation letter, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. I now have no ties. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn't trade places with me, they envy my lack of responsibilities. I'm no longer in a relationship, and I have no strong career ambitions. I feel almost obliged to make the most of this freedom - if only for my friends' sake! Why am I so nervous? First, it's about making the necessary arrangements. How could I let someone else live in my home? And how would I organize the rental? And besides, I had to decide where to go. I'm a terrible procrastinator and am already several weeks behind my planned schedule. 'Might as well enjoy the summer in England,' I told myself. Then, 'Why not stay for the start of the football season?' Cutting emotional ties makes it even harder. I'm delaying because, deep down, I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among young backpackers just out of school and university? Maybe not. I've found it's more common for Britons in their late twenties and thirties to want to leave their lives behind and travel to foreign places. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet guidebook publishers, says more people realize that adventure is possible: 'People who always say "I wish I'd had that opportunity" are realizing they can have it anytime they want. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.' For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, it's a chance to have one last adventure before settling down. They have bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I'm ready to give up job security for the trip,' says Danny. 'There's always a small worry that, "OK, I'm not moving up the career ladder, I'll be in the same position when I come back," but I think it's a risk you have to take. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a symbolic act of defiance!' For Matt, who just left the Army, the year he spent traveling was a time of change. 'In the military, there's a set way of doing things, a pattern to how you solve problems. I went away because I needed to change this, and get rid of this approach in some cases, to have a reasonable life as a civilian.' While there are many reasons to travel at my age, there seem to be common factors. 'We have a more flexible workforce today,' says Angela Baron of the Institute of Personnel Development. 'More people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you've got nothing to lose.' Larger companies are even adopting career-break policies. 'If you've spent a lot of time and money training someone, it's nice to know they're coming back at some point rather than going to work for a competitor.' For Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a publishing company that focuses on the stories of 'ordinary' travelers, more thirty-somethings are rethinking their lives. 'If you're not happy with what you're doing - and many people aren't - it's no longer about just sticking with it. Now people know that opportunities exist and that a job isn't "for life" anymore. Travel offers a chance to reassess, to step back and think about your life.' Is giving in to wanderlust just another example of my generation's struggle with adulthood? Jennifer Cox thinks not. 'It's a sign of a better-educated, more stable society when we're less worried about paying the bills and more about living a balanced life. We're actually taking the time to ask "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn't believe he's running away. 'It's more about running towards something. It's trying to get some things that I want for myself.' But he does feel some fear. 'It's the thought of what I'm leaving behind, that comfortable routine - just going into the office every day, saying "hi" to everyone, and sitting down with a cup of coffee.' I share Ben's worries about leaving behind an ordered life with few challenges, and I'm not sure I'd be making this journey if I hadn't found my boss so unbearable. As Jennifer Cox points out: 'This is fairly typical. There's often a catalyst, like the end of a relationship or the loss of a job. Such an event can push people to go and do it.' It may have taken a helpful push to get me moving, but I'm now looking forward to the next 12 months with growing excitement. Whatever happens, I'll be able to take satisfaction in having taken control of my life. And in that, I'm sure I speak for all of us older backpackers.'

**Plugging in the Home**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt out of touch with new technology. She shares how she turned her family home into an efficient workplace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to restart my journalism career, which I thought was lost due to technology. My resume showed I was stuck in the 1980s, when typewriters were the latest technology. It seemed unlikely anyone would hire me to work on a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads asked for desktop publishing experience, which I didn't have. I felt I had a better chance of teaching nuclear physics than using a computer to design a page. I was the family technophobe; even pocket calculators confused me, and I couldn't use the video timer. Clearly, I needed to act quickly to save my career.

I thought leaving home before the children did would be difficult until I entered a competition in a local newspaper. Like a story you hear about but never expect to happen to you, my family and I won a computer package. We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We entered a new world where terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became common in our vocabulary. We started chatting with strangers around the world via the Internet. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a mini-office in the kitchen with a phone-answering machine, a fax, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home and still take the children to school.

The children were confident with computers from the start, as they learned about them at school. I was more hesitant, worried that I would lose all my work if I pressed the wrong button. I was wrong. Although not an expert, I learned the basic skills I needed. It was logical, easy, and foolproof. With perseverance, you learn a little more each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to have the best of both worlds.

How has the computer helped me? Since school, I have always worked at a messy desk, often losing important notes. The computer has made me an organized worker, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help me track income and expenses, and pre-formatted invoices and letterheads save me time and effort. For a journalist, being online means I can research stories, ask for more information in journalism forums, and discuss working from home with people worldwide.

If this sounds too good to be true, there is a downside to working from home. You can feel isolated from people. There are distractions, like doing urgent housework first, and when the children are home, we argue over who gets to use the computer. However, more people are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education, leisure, and entertainment. In my street, a new type of home business is growing because people don't have to commute to the city every day.

So, what characterizes home workers as we move into the next century? A report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated; 93% own a personal computer, and 32% have a CD-ROM device; 38% have a laser printer, and 50% have a modem. Considering this, I seem to be ahead of schedule. Who knows, one day I might email a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or, better yet, publish my own magazine from home. It seems the sky, or should I say cyberspace, is the limit.

**The Tartan Museum**

The new Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh has a modern design that stands out in its historic location. Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened to see if its contents were as impressive as its exterior. The museum is hard to miss with its large, yellow sandstone tower and unique building shape. Last winter, the building received mixed reviews, from praise to criticism. Now, as the museum prepares to open, the exhibitions are expected to receive similar reactions.

The museum tells Scotland's story through various historic objects, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels. It provides a timeline to help visitors understand the displays without overwhelming them with national pride. The main question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, head of exhibitions, wants the museum to be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. He avoids using too much imagination in displays, preferring to show what experts know to be true.

The museum uses explanation panels, captions, and some multimedia to tell the stories of the objects. With less than three days before opening, it's still uncertain how effective this will be. However, the museum's design is impressive, with galleries that flow into each other and plenty of natural light.

The museum also has a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a Junior Board of 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland. Although the children wanted to ride through the displays, they got a hands-on center instead. The Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition, featuring objects chosen by Scottish people and others that impacted life in Scotland. While the idea is fun, it might seem less serious until the computerised personal stories are added next week.

Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that objects can vividly show the past. The modern architecture works well inside, but whether it fits the location is still debated.

The end of print may take some time

Peter Preston

Transition is a nice word. It means moving smoothly from the present to the future. But when it comes to newspapers moving online, the process is not smooth or certain. Many people think it will happen because print newspaper sales are going down while visits to their websites are going up. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% in a year, but their website visits are increasing. This seems true, but it depends on many factors like timing and location.

The World Association of Newspapers says global newspaper circulation went up by 1.1% last year, mostly because of growth in Asia, even though sales in the West went down. News magazines also saw a 5.4% increase. Books show a similar trend. E-readers like Kindle are selling well, but the value of physical books sold only dropped by 0.4%. So, both digital and print are important.

The idea that young people are not reading newspapers is not entirely true. Nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 read the main national newspapers. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, print sales dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop was only 7%, and in France, it was 3.1%.

In the past, people thought online ads would make online newspapers successful. But now, digital ad revenue is falling, and many US newspapers have started charging for online content. The best way to get people to pay is to offer both print and digital access together. Print is still important for selling online subscriptions, and print ads make much more money than online ads.

This situation is not easy for newspaper companies because running both print and online editions is costly. However, newspapers still have a strong presence in print, and being noticed online is harder.

**Photographing People**

People are very interesting subjects for photos. A picture with a person in it is usually more engaging than one without. However, taking good photos of people can be challenging. Besides technical and artistic aspects, photographers need to pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, the camera can make people act unnaturally.

**A. GROUPING PEOPLE**

Avoid straight lines in group photos. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances, or on different levels. You can also have some people sitting or kneeling in front so that all faces are visible, or take the photo from a higher position.

**B. POSING FOR PICTURES**

People often act unnaturally in front of a camera. They might become stiff. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. THE RIGHT APPROACH**

Don't pretend you are not taking a picture when you clearly are, as this can create tension. Most people will agree to be photographed, even if they protest at first. They might become self-conscious, so you may need to guide them. A photo can be ruined if the person is looking away aimlessly.

**D. EYE CONTACT**

A photo has more impact if the person is looking at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don't have to smile. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.

**E. CANDID CONCENTRATION**

Instead of direct eye contact, the person can focus on something in the picture. This might be easier for them, and the viewer can follow their gaze. Candid shots are interesting, and the person's expression is important.

**F. EXPRESSIONS AND GESTURES**

Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about the person in a photo. A laughing child makes the viewer smile, while a sad expression can make the viewer feel sympathy. Look for familiar expressions like shrugs, winks, or thumbs-up. They are a universal visual language.

**G. SITUATION INTEREST**

Photos that show a person with their background can be more interesting. The background can add information about the person. Try to exclude irrelevant details or blur them. Make sure the background doesn't overpower the subject. A wide-angle lens can help make the person stand out.

**H. INTERACTION**

When two or more people are interacting, there are chances for good photos. Couples, mothers and babies, or teams working together make appealing shots. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Capture how one person reacts to another with expressions or gestures.

**I. PEOPLE AND PLACES**

Many photos of people are taken on holidays to show the places they visit. To improve these photos, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the whole scene. Ask people to stand close to the camera, so they are in the foreground without blocking the background. An elevated camera position can help balance the people and the place in the photo.

**J. TO POSE OR NOT TO POSE?**

Decide why you want to take the picture. If it's to remember someone you met briefly, ask them to pose against a nice background. Family photos can be boring if they are all formal poses. Candid photos of events are more lively, and you can get natural shots when you know the person well. A spontaneous picture can bring back memories better than a posed one.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist. Her paintings trick the eye by creating the illusion of reality. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her.

Sarah Janson is an artist who doesn't sign her work unless asked. She believes the work is more important than the artist. Janson is very modest and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes her a bit shy in interviews. She doesn't like talking about herself and feels uncomfortable being photographed.

However, once she relaxes, the interview becomes interesting and funny. Janson has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But illustration didn't satisfy her, so she joined a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to do a trompe-l'oeil, and she found her passion. She then started her own business, feeling she was on the right path.

Janson's skills in observation and detail, learned from illustrating, are important for trompe-l'oeil. She believes no one can teach you trompe-l'oeil; it's about observing life. She says she is still learning and is honest about her weaknesses, like not being able to paint bread well.

Janson sometimes doubts herself, especially with big projects like the chapel ceiling at Lulworth Castle. She often talks about herself in the third person, as if her talent is separate from her.

Her work is unique and stands out from others who try trompe-l'oeil. She has many important projects, often inspired by architecture. For example, she painted a dining room to look like a Venetian palace and a corridor that seems to lead to more rooms.

Trompe-l'oeil must first trick you and then keep your interest. Janson believes it should also be personal to the client. She enjoys working with clients and getting ideas from them. Many clients become her friends because she spends a lot of time with them during projects.

Janson appreciates her clients and is thankful for those who trust her with their walls. Despite her modesty, she is always busy. She repeats that she doesn't like to boast about herself or her work. But her work is impressive and deserves more recognition.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman talks about the 'people skills' needed to succeed in your career.

**A** The way we are judged at work is changing. It's not just about how smart we are or our training, but also how we handle ourselves and others. This new way of judging is important for deciding who gets hired or promoted. It can show who might become a top performer and who might not. These skills are important for future jobs, no matter what field we work in. They are different from what we learned in school. Doing well in exams doesn't matter much here. This new measure assumes we all have enough intelligence and technical skills. It focuses on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are called emotional intelligence.

**B** In a time when job security is uncertain, personal qualities are important at work. These have been called 'character', 'personality', or 'soft skills'. Now, they are known as 'emotional intelligence'. This means being able to understand and manage your own and others' feelings, and using them to guide actions. At work, it includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some think it means just 'being nice', but sometimes it means being honest, even if it's uncomfortable. It doesn't mean expressing all feelings freely, but managing them well to help people work together towards a common goal.

**C** More businesses see emotional intelligence as important for management. The more complex the job, the more these skills matter. Lack of emotional intelligence can make it hard to use technical skills or intelligence. Some people succeed without it, but as work becomes more complex and team-based, companies where people work well together have an advantage. In today's workplace, with a focus on teamwork and customer service, emotional intelligence is essential for success everywhere.

**D** Unlike IQ, which changes little, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. Studies show people get better at handling emotions, motivating themselves, and improving social skills over time. This growth is often called maturity. Emotional intelligence can be learned, and we can add these skills to help us survive in uncertain job markets. It's not a magic solution for struggling companies, but ignoring the human aspect can make everything else less effective.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important events, but social media has changed citizen photography even more. News often first appears on social networks, so some journalists use them to find images when events happen quickly. Unfortunately, some reporters have used user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. There is official advice that images on social media can be used without permission if there are special circumstances or strong public interest, but people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, so UGC is important for the future of the media. However, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media must make sure people are properly rewarded for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West: Acupuncture**

Acupuncture is a practice that is 2,000 years old. It is part of traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many conditions, but it is most known in the West for helping with pain. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for pain relief.

**A. What is Acupuncture?**

Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, the body can become unbalanced, leading to illness. A traditional acupuncturist will try to find where the Qi is imbalanced by checking your pulse, looking at your tongue, and asking about your health, mood, and habits. They use fine needles inserted into the skin and may also use heat or pressure to help the flow of Qi.

**B. Over Three Hundred Points**

The points used in acupuncture are related to meridians and may not be near the area of pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This can be done by hand or with an electro-acupuncture machine. Acupuncturists say this feeling shows the needle has reached the Qi. There are over 300 points on the main meridians, with many more used less often.

**C. Scientific Explanations**

Even without accepting traditional Chinese medicine, some doctors believe acupuncture can help with pain. They have scientific ideas about how it might work, such as: 
- Stimulating certain nerves to block pain signals from reaching the brain.
- Releasing natural pain-relieving substances called endorphins.

**D. Types of Pain Treated**

Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture as a last option. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**E. Modern Use for an Ancient Treatment**

Although acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, using it instead of anesthesia during surgery began in the 1950s. This helped convince some doctors outside China of its effectiveness. In China, acupuncture is used in many surgeries, including heart surgery. It can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with drugs. It is said to reduce pain, but results vary. Acupuncture anesthesia has fewer side effects than traditional anesthesia, like nausea, and recovery is quicker.

**F. Effectiveness**

Clinical trials for acupuncture are hard to conduct, but some show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists agree with this success rate but acknowledge it doesn't work for everyone. For chronic pain, relief usually takes six to seven visits, but some improvement should be felt after two or three visits.

**G. A Different Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine view pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just symptoms. They spend time diagnosing and finding weaknesses in the Qi. They also consider external factors like weather and the type of pain. This approach is different from that of most medical doctors.

**H. Traditional or Not?**

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that only by using traditional Chinese medicine can deep changes and long-term cures be achieved. It is important to choose an acupuncturist carefully, and they should refer you to a doctor if needed.

**P.D. James: A Master of Crime Writing**

P.D. James, whose full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, is a famous crime writer. She seems calm and confident, and one might imagine her as a headmistress of a girls' school if she hadn't become a writer. However, her confidence hides her shyness. She admits that her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is somewhat based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Like Dalgliesh, she prefers to work alone, especially when writing. She needs privacy to write and can do so almost anywhere as long as she is alone.

Despite her success, P.D. James is humble and does not agree with the idea that she is Britain's most famous crime writer, even though her 12 detective novels are loved by millions worldwide. She enjoys the works of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. She also reads books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she appreciates male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh as well.

P.D. James found success later in life. Now in her seventies, she published her first crime novel, "Cover Her Face," at the age of 42. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge, where she met her husband, Connor Bantry White, a student at the university. She chose Cambridge as the setting for her book "An Unsuitable Job For A Woman."

Her life has had its challenges. Her husband returned from World War II very ill, and she had to work long hours to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped by taking care of the children during those tough times. While working full-time for the National Health Service, she managed five psychiatric clinics. Later, she worked for 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and then in the Criminal Law section.

Her work in forensic science made her familiar with the sight of corpses, but it was the structure of crime novels that interested her, not death itself. She always wanted to be a writer and saw writing detective stories as a way to learn how to be a serious novelist. She believes that even within the classic detective story format, one can write meaningful novels about people. Writing detective stories, she says, is a way to bring order to chaos. Solving a crime shows the value of life, even if that life is not lovable. She believes that nobody truly likes violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you might be asked for a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting could help decide if you are suitable for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help identify certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and can show psychological states and emotional issues. Handwriting analysis is being used more for career guidance and during job interviews. Many big companies hire graphologists to study the handwriting of candidates for important jobs. However, most doctors and psychiatrists are doubtful about the value of graphology.

Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, believes doctors should take it more seriously. She thinks handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should focus on arts or sciences, and if they have a devious or open character." According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be useful in assessing possible criminal tendencies: "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, mostly poorly-shaped. Many criminals come from deprived backgrounds and have stopped emotional development. This often appears in childish handwriting and in going over letters several times."

Ms. Marne can tell if people are honest, manipulative, or reliable employees. "Young male offenders often have very high ascenders, showing they live in a world of fantasy and dream of success. Graphologists can tell if violence is about to happen, if the writer is under too much pressure, and if there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can be used to predict potential suicides." Heart and lung problems can also appear, she says. "You can't diagnose from one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. But if it changes over time or becomes disjointed, or if there's a break in the signature that wasn't there before, it could mean something serious has happened." A severe emotional upset can also show in a temporarily changed signature, she says.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can reveal other psychological traits. People whose letters form 'threads' instead of being individually formed are, apparently, devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals are trying to hide their true selves. Very light pressure indicates sensitivity and lack of energy. Originality in handwriting—how much the writer has changed from standard script—shows confidence and artistic ability. Disconnected writing is a sign of a loner. Very small signatures indicate inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a bid for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word is a sign of intolerance and a patronizing attitude.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, and this must be combined with empathy and intuition. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a proper science. She thinks this will happen soon. "It's actually more accurate than psychoanalysis, as you can tell the whole history of the person, including all their emotional crises, without asking them questions they might answer incorrectly."

Although this sounds interesting, there is little solid evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists are very critical. They say handwriting is a result of education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taught—and has no other significance.

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and the right chairs are important for a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were as working environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, and windows open directly to the street. It is hard to see why this space works, but the team, who are part of a small, dynamic group, seem to have few complaints. They adapt to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, much like they do at home. This might be the key: a team of seven people have created a happy, homely working environment without any outside rules.

Ergonomist: The furniture here is mismatched and often creates bad working postures. Chairs are old, most aren't adjustable, and many are broken. Although this is not ideal, the staff have a varied work schedule, which they control—office work, meeting clients, making presentations, etc. This variety reduces the risk of fatigue, boredom, and muscle problems.

Occupational Psychologist: Staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. They said their office was 'just the right size'—small enough to know what colleagues are doing, large enough to focus on personal work. I found the office attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.

Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office may not be exciting, but it is comfortable and the staff do not dislike it. The air quality and maintenance are good, helped by a No Smoking policy.

Ergonomist: The company has already used an ergonomist. Chairs are excellent, lighting and computer equipment are good. Space is good, but the layout could be better. The environment is impersonal and dull, with grey, bare walls.

Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for at least five years and relationships are okay. The office could be better if desks were arranged to share information more easily. Success stories or project information could be displayed on the walls.

Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: This office gets mixed reactions. It feels like being in a glass case, viewing and being viewed by many similar setups. Despite smokers and non-smokers in a small space, the air did not seem stale. Even standing 1.5 meters from a smoker, you couldn't smell the cigarette.

Ergonomist: The office is very standard and uninspiring. Desks are just adequate. Not all chairs meet requirements, but this is user choice. Computer screens are often on small desks with lowered keyboard shelves, which is outdated.

Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and are well-served by technology. Many communication awards are displayed. The wood-colored panels and brown carpet give a slightly serious effect. The office is busy.

Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: It is hard to say anything good about this building. The air-conditioning control is basic, causing big temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most people have inadequate desk space. The office is very dusty, with many places for dust to settle. The roof also collects dust, which can fall on people below.

Ergonomist: The furniture looks more suitable for a carpentry workshop than a high-tech industry. Most chairs are not good for keyboard users, especially those shorter than 1.75 m. Many chairs are old, lack adjustment, and have armrests that prevent getting close to the desk.

Occupational Psychologist: Old brown chairs, dirty carpets, dust, and dirt everywhere. There is a lot of room for improvement—the place needs a good clean-up, individual success could be more recognized, and air conditioning needs immediate improvement—there are many smokers. Few conversations were happening when we visited; everyone seemed stressed and driven by deadlines. The company needs to adopt team-working.'

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular and classless, with Americans chewing 12 million sticks every day. Learn how this ancient habit became a big business. Each stick of gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered a food and must meet the American Food and Drug Administration's standards. Modern gum is mostly synthetic, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and improve texture. 

In the past, the ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women used mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, spruce gum was sold in the eastern United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum there.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla commercially have failed, so synthetic alternatives were developed as the market grew.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a tough and dangerous job. They travel long distances in high humidity to collect sapodilla sap. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects, including the chicle fly, which lays eggs in their ears and nose. Using only a rope and an axe, a skilled chiclero climbs a tree to cut the bark and collect the sap. The sap is then carried to a camp, boiled until sticky, and made into bricks. Life at the camp is hard, with a simple maize-based diet and local alcohol.

Despite the harsh conditions, chicleros worry about their jobs. The U.S. once imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle a year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers use synthetics to cut costs and meet demand.

Gum producers are finding new ways to market their products. Gum is said to help you relax, boost energy, and reduce tension. Soldiers in both world wars were given gum. Its biggest claim is that it reduces tooth decay. Plaque acid from eating causes decay, but saliva neutralizes the acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Chewing gum for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.

Research continues on new textures and flavors. Glycerine and vegetable oil products are used to blend the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural help. Also, 137 square kilometers of America are used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calm of an English country house with Indian symbolism. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The facilities are simple, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity adds to its charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I discovered it by accident while climbing. After reaching the top of a glacier and walking down, I was surprised to find this hotel. It is in a beautiful, wild area, high up in the mountains. After a tiring climb, finding such luxury, with someone playing Cole Porter on the piano, was amazing.

**C. MAURITIUS - BEACHCOMBER PARADIS HOTEL**  
Located on the south-west of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is on its own peninsula in a quiet part of the island. The road to the hotel winds along the coast past empty beaches. The hotel is not small, and many people enjoy the free watersports, but you can find solitude along nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone leaves, you can sit on the beach and feel far away from everything.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia is in a dramatic Caribbean setting. It is quiet and remote, standing 1,000 feet high, with open rooms that look out between the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The style is colonial, with furniture made of mahogany and greenheart wood, and beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
This hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a perfect escape from Istanbul's noise. The islands are an hour away by boat and are idyllic. There are no cars, only horse-drawn carriages and beautiful wooden architecture from the 1920s. The Splendid Hotel is a landmark, painted white with red domes, resembling a hotel from the French Riviera. It is a bit worn now but still charming.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the heart of Champagne, is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. Surrounded by a moat with swans, the chateau was a family home until recently. It has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one even has a billiard table. There are special weekend rates that include breakfast, dinner, and complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview is a comfortable hotel in Africa that avoids flashy luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers resting from one safari and planning the next. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens, rooms, and dining menu. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city center. It's a great place to watch the African sunset while enjoying a drink and a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Duke of Windsor was the first to sign the guest book at Hotel Splendido. Since then, many famous people have visited, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet a wealthy businessperson. This former monastery-turned-hotel is still splendid, with simple yet delicious food and beautiful Persian rugs.

**The Hotel Inspector**

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. 

At the Globe Hotel, things start badly. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue. Sue whispers, "Very poor." This is a common mistake she has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. The Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide Sue works for. 

The entrance to the hotel is not welcoming. Sue had to enter through an unmanned door and walk down a long, empty corridor. "Not what I expected," she says. 

Things get worse when the receptionist says they have no record of Sue's booking. Most of the hotel's rooms are empty that night. Sue is given a room on the top floor, but she does not like it. It is stuffy, and there is a large hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

Sue was known for being tough when she started her job. "The Woman in Black," she recalls, though she never wore black. The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He looks worried. He apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge, saying there might be a blocked drain. Sue suggests not taking guests to that lounge until it is fixed. Greaves agrees and takes notes. He has been at the hotel for only five months and hopes Sue's feedback will help improve the hotel.

Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, a waitress, for their good work. Dinner was good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks how to get three rosettes. Sue suggests not serving a pudding that collapses. 

Sue's job is to say what other guests might be too afraid to say. Sometimes people complain about her, but she has to tell the truth. She also writes a full report for the hotel. Hotels pay to be in the guide, so they want to know how to improve. 

Greaves is relieved to hear that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. However, another inspector will visit in the next two months to check if improvements have been made. "Good," says Greaves, trying to sound positive.

**Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experiences of climbing the highest peak on each continent: the Seven Summits.**

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
My journey to climb the Seven Summits started later in life. I will describe them in the order I climbed them. On Mt. Everest, my partner Dougal Haston and I were in a snow cave 91 meters below the summit. Dougal started talking to our Equipment Officer, Dave Clark, about sleeping bags, even though only Dougal and I were there. I thought it was due to lack of oxygen. I also found myself talking to my feet, which were getting cold. I remembered other climbers who had lost fingers and toes to frostbite. We were more concerned about how we would survive rather than if we would survive. Over the next two days, I thought about our time on the summit ridge. I realized Dougal was the best partner I could have had. He gave me confidence, and I felt calm, believing everything would work out. I knew I needed a better rhythm to reach the summit, and I did.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is considered one of the most dangerous in the world. In April 1976, Dougal and I arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day of climbing, we realized how big our task was. We followed a route from 1967 on the lower face, but halfway up, we took a new route to the upper snow basin and summit. We climbed 'alpine style,' carrying our equipment and food. It was the first time a major new route was climbed this way. We camped under a rocky cliff, and by the third day, my sleeping bag was wet. We spent the third night on a windy ridge, and we were both suffering. The air pressure in polar regions is lower, making it feel like we were at 7,000m instead of 6,100m. We packed our bags and finally reached the summit and descended, feeling triumphant.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Paul Braithwaite and I flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. However, we got a free ride to the Tanzanian side of Kilimanjaro and decided to climb Africa's highest mountain. We got lost in the dense jungles of the lower slopes, and water was scarce. On the second day, we found arrows painted on trees and a trail of rubbish leading to a rock pool. I was never so happy to find rubbish on a mountain. We tried a direct start to the breach wall, a 305m-high icicle, but after falling rock and ice, we chose the Umbwe route to reach the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
The standard route up Aconcagua is mostly a walk. In January 1992, I arrived with my wife, Sharu, at Punta del Inca and met fellow mountaineer Phil Erscheler. He was guiding a group up the mountain via the Polish Glacier and invited us to join. After three days of bad weather, we left base camp. The Polish Glacier was icy and windy. With a time limit to return to Buenos Aires, we skipped the glacier and took the north ridges to the standard route, joining many others. The wind was strong as we reached the summit, and we camped outside the refuge before dark. Back at base camp, we met members of the Jakarta Mountaineering Club, who were planning to climb the Seven Summits. They encouraged me to do the same, which I hadn't seriously considered before.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
I learned that climbing Vinson Massif was possible by guiding enough people to cover the costs. Attempting all Seven Summits became a reality. Our team left Britain in November 1992 and traveled to the South Pole. At this time of year, the sun is always above the horizon, and when the wind stops, it's very quiet. On December 7, we left camp for the summit. Despite winds of 80 km/h and temperatures below minus 50°C, we reached the top in 8 hours. Our joy was lessened by the storm, which reduced visibility to a few meters.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
Our team gathered in St Petersburg in early summer 1994. At Terskol, near Elbrus, a commission was requested from our guide for bringing foreigners, but it was later waived. After a few days of acclimatizing, we took a cableway to 3,900m and walked to a refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, we crossed icy slopes in strong winds. By mid-afternoon, we thought we reached the summit, but there was another ridge to the actual summit. As night fell, we returned to the refuge and descended the next day.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On our expedition to Carstensz, we aimed to establish a new route and spend time with the aboriginal Dani people. The largest gold mine in the world is cutting into the mountain, sacred to the local tribes. We were warned about bandits but continued our journey. On May 12, we started climbing. The weather improved, and two team members went ahead. We were slower because Sham was filming. We reached the summit by 11 am, and I received a standing ovation for completing my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

Text: 'Style Merchants Style is important in our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares the trends for this year's fashion followers. Ned Ingham: Dress Designer Ned Ingham creates dreamy, romantic wedding dresses. 'People should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and the 'frilly' look and choose simpler styles,' he says. Ingham has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school, where he learned how to cut and make clothes. But you don't have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress: he also designs long, classic evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, Ingham offers a summer navy-blue suit, a staple in the Englishwoman's wardrobe for most of the 20th century. In his hands, it looks as new as tomorrow. Sally Quail: Jeweller Sally Quail once worked for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery. When she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked, she decided to design her own. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many stars look for her pieces. Her style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by 18th-century jewellery. Recently, she started using diamonds. 'It must reflect my age,' says 36-year-old Quail. 'I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond, so I began working with them.' Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer Just four years after starting in the competitive fashion business, Lily Grimson, with only a basic course in art and design, has had two of her creations chosen for a major design exhibition. Her designs are always noticed. All of Grimson's fashion bags are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is not just a container - they are full of glamour, made from the finest calfskin or heavy silk. A mix of style and care makes a Grimson bag special. Peter Little: Hairdresser For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of some of the world's top people. 'Most women want natural-looking hair and a style they can manage at home,' he says. His approach is unique - to make sure his clients never look like they just left a salon. But this relaxed look is not cheap - £250 for the first appointment, and there's a three-month waiting list. Using his fame, Peter has created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools. Now, those who can't visit his salon can style their hair at home. Penny Pratt: Florist Besides running her small shop, Penny Pratt is a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain and gives floral ideas to top restaurants. This is impressive for someone with no formal training in floristry who left her teaching job 10 years ago to do 'something different'. Her simple, yet modern, creations have won many design prizes in the flower business, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, 'Flower arrangements are simpler these days. Keep them simple but strong and don't use too many leaves - they are too large and architectural. For wedding bouquets, the rule is: the flowers must be of the same type.' '

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large eighteenth-century houses into this hotel. This project allowed the hotel to install the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. 

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. At the Merrion, a high-tech system allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C. 

Business travelers will appreciate the technology in their rooms. MacCann expects that up to 65% of the hotel's business will come from this market. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by installing extra cables and renting televisions, so they can be easily updated. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed.

Despite all this technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also offers a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the Merrion must be excellent, as expected in luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He has a new, modern kitchen and better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular and successful restaurant without financial risks. With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, especially in the two long flower borders along the path. This is partly thanks to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, 'It was really his garden.' They got along well, and he understood her ideas when she explained she wanted to paint certain plants.

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, 'I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one.' Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they age fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being put in water.

Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and thought garden flowers looked fake. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rocks or cliffs. Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.
