They got along well, and he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint certain plants.

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they grow, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, 'I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one.' Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they decay fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up when left in water.

Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and thought garden flowers looked fake. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.

With two upcoming exhibitions, Susan has less time to work in the garden. She hired another gardener but knows that to stay connected to her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

Title: Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experience as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year working there. Known as Pilch, she works for a company that provides cooking and cleaning services for visitors who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses typical of the area.

Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl is not a career but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski and enjoys skiing as much as possible. "On a good day, we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she does not nap. "It's fatal if you do," she says. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and loads the dishwasher. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she says. Sometimes she chats with the guests, while other times they prefer to be left alone. "Good guests can make a week brilliant, but some weeks don't go quite so well," she says.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening," she says. However, she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. "A frightful day," she says, "when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted."

On Sunday, work starts earlier because breakfast for departing guests must be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet thoroughly. "We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready," she says. If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. "Sometimes they are disoriented and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them," she says.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it's time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night," she says.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the offices of the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't usually stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, but maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, went on location with the TV gardening programme Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, because of my shifts, I never see daylight. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of landscape gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I was more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint doing some jobs, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is a waste of time compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with the airline Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different—people suddenly respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journeys**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past amazing sea views. No matter the weather or time of year, it's always beautiful. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I've worn it ever since. What I remember most is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable—we were just given a day. We heard the driver would wait for days if people were still coming. When it arrived, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages—some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train crossed beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw few trains. As a teenager, I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming was on an old, unused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I returned last year, it was like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Trying to get published? If you are wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs is here with the advice you need. Readers of this magazine often ask, 'I have written this story or book. Can you please tell me who to send it to?' One of the first things they need to know is that they should research their markets and learn about publishers while also improving their writing skills. Turning words into something that can be sold requires a lot of knowledge about the 'writing game'. Whatever kind of writing you do, you need to understand the markets you are aiming for. There are several ways to do this, but the best one is by reading everything relevant you can find. Use your local library and visit local bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will always give you the best idea of what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any given time. As time goes on, this knowledge must be updated because new publications are constantly appearing, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles are coming and going all the time. Publishers are always looking for new writers; as writers, we have to make sure we give them what they want. To begin with, you may be looking around, not quite sure what you want to write. Let's say you feel that you might like to write short love stories. The first thing you must do is find out which magazines use love stories, a rather limited market these days, and get as many recent copies as you can. Then, familiarize yourself with the kind of stories they are buying, paying special attention to who the readers are. These readers will expect different things from their magazine, and the editor is only interested in meeting their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - please tell me if I am wasting my time ... do I stand a chance at all?' As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. But it is unlikely that the work is of publishable standard, so I have to try to give an honest opinion, but always with a positive viewpoint. The problem is that most new writers are too eager to send their work out, usually long before they are ready to enter the market. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not likely to be published. That almost never happens. When you read about 'success', you usually find that the person has been in the publishing trade or journalism for some years before their current success. When you finally send off some of your work for the first time, immediately get on with more work while you wait for a reply; write ten more stories, twenty even. Each one will be better than the last, and you will begin to think of yourself as a writer, and both your fluency and your confidence will grow. Don't throw any of them away—improve them instead. Also, I would advise not showing your work to anyone else, especially in the early stages. Don't forget that every successful writer will have had many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your career as a writer. See if there's a creative writing course near you. If not, try joining a local writers' group, which will help you gain ideas and confidence from mixing with other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.'

Text: 'No Title On the last day of a bad year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station didn't feel as airy and clean as usual. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students sat on the floor with their bags. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, soft beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question, then approached a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn't mind talking to her. The man asked, 'Are you travelling to Philadelphia?' 'Well, northbound, yes,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 'Ma'am,' I heard him ask an old lady, 'are you travelling to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn't. I probably seemed unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the bench at the other end. He looked stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She lowered her book. She was around thirty-five, older than me. A school-teacher type. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favour?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my left wrist. (I don't own a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too difficult, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving to Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags like pets on leashes. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter's flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; didn't know what to do.' The woman clucked sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where this was going. 'I told her to stay put. Stay in the station, I said, and I would get someone here to bring her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a poor excuse, in my opinion. Also, it was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have made more sense, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel the contents! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Watch yourself, lady, I thought.'

**Gary and Me**

The restaurant owner, John Moore, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary's chance was with cooking, and John's chance was to run a restaurant. When John found out about the opportunity to own a restaurant, he quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for his plans. Starting this business reminded John of his childhood. He remembers his mother working in a factory and feeling upset because he was left alone. Because of this, he wanted to make time for family life. His wife took care of the children and managed the accounts, while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made sure to have meals together. This was very beneficial for their children, Gary and Joe, who became very confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a great start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined and would wake up even before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and it was nice to see Gary doing his part. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adults working there and sometimes was even in charge. He could make over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would go into catering because he had a natural talent. When Gary needed to do work experience for school, John sent him to a friend's restaurant.

Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if the music becomes successful. John's advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can achieve. John told Gary, "If you want to succeed in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If not, it might be too late." Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he and the other new students, who were usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But Gary finished everything in an hour and helped others. John is very proud of Gary's successful TV cookery series. He always told Gary that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one will give it to you. Gary saw his opportunity and took it. John says that if children remember even a little of what their parents tell them, it's good. The things Gary says and does show that he listened sometimes.

Finding a good flat in Dublin at an affordable price was very difficult, like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way was through personal contacts: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often worked. But if, like Jo, you had just arrived in Dublin, you had no personal contacts, no one to tell you about a vacant bedsit. So, it was a matter of staying in a hostel and searching. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going. Everyone at her school assumed she would go. Who would stay in a small, remote town? That's all she heard for years. They all wanted to leave, see some life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family would help them settle. But none from Jo's year were going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, run by nuns, where she would be safe. Her father hoped they kept the place warm, as hostels were known for being cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay a whole week in a hostel. But Jo didn't know they were all still thinking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. Please, let it be nice, let them like me, let it not be too expensive! There wasn't a queue for this one because it was more 'Third Girl Wanted' than 'Flat to Let'. The 'own television' part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, obviously a failed applicant, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said the girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand that type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and giggled, saying, "Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, Jo noted with surprise. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called.' Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said 'Nessa', one said 'Pauline', and the other said 'Other'. 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are decreasing in number.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" have made us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas today. For example, the number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000.

You might think dolphins are protected by law and live in safe areas. But this is not true, and not having plans to protect them could become a big wildlife problem. There are 40 different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups. We know little about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in Scotland's Moray Firth and Wales' Cardigan Bay. The few that remain show signs of stress.

Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to know why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which reduces fish stocks and threatens local fishing, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are overfished in one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses large nets that float or are pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornish beaches. Marks on their bodies show they died from getting caught in nets.

Waste and chemicals in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they accumulate in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk with high pesticide levels, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk.

Perhaps the most debated threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels chaotic. You might think, "Not another article about fitness!" But there are many articles because exercise is really good for you. There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to.

Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps your muscles work better and improves your posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. Good posture prevents muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise also helps specific areas like thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It makes your heart and lungs healthier and improves blood circulation.

You might have heard these reasons many times and feel bored. But did you know exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems? It also helps control stress and can improve some medical conditions. These reasons should convince you that exercise is good for you. If not, just think about it: common sense says exercise is beneficial.

There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or weight training. Remember, training too hard or with too much weight can cause injuries, so start slowly. If you're unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.

Good posture is important for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body looks unattractive and lacks energy. If you slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling your head up. This helps lift your chest for better breathing and makes your body look slimmer. When standing, if your chest is balanced, you should see your ankles.

Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine and should be done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period. Doing this four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? It's their search for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest people to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost nonstop rain, causing many unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive tool so that whenever one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. His partnership with the talented producer has created some of TV's best wildlife films, like their amazing film on leopards. Even while this film about Africa's shyest cats was being shown, they were already back in the wild, this time following the equally shy jackal. But this is common in television partnerships. Travelling film-makers have been going around the world to film exotic wildlife since television began.

I spoke to Newman about their partnership while he was briefly meeting other people at a safari lodge. 'We do have occasional arguments but we get over them quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and he says they get along well because they both see the animals in a similar way. 'When we are moving, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we have a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each morning, we make the tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask.' The rest of their daily diet is pre-packed meals heated and served by whoever is available. 'It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so food can be a bit of a worry,' says Newman. It can be a tough life, but being alone in such remote areas allows them to get close to the animals and become part of their lives. Newman remembers filming a family of lions where one lioness would regularly go off on her own. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions, and after a while, she even greeted their car as part of her routine.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift', and two years later, they went as a team to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they start, they have to submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I developed a good working relationship from the start,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We always aim to create a film that is rich in atmosphere, brings to life the true spirit of the place and animals, and touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is better than just appealing to their minds.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her typical day includes teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'

'My whole life is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. She follows a strict schedule to be very fit. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start well.'

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of talent.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, there's only one chance.'

In her 15 years of playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we're all friendlier.' Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, she believes in having a strong mental attitude and leading by example. She supports and encourages her team.

'From the start, my netball career was carefully planned,' she says. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, about the size of a small car, and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is very limited. Rachel can touch the two pilots, and they can't stand up or move much. They have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant journey.

Rachel didn't know how she would feel the first time she got into the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. On the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment there to study the effect of a program that would make a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she loves, but she does it so she can continue her research into the "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out at a speed of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.

The only time Rachel was scared was when she first went down with the Americans. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was an explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. She studied the black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., and seeing them in real life was an amazing experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, and our tone of voice, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I finally graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. One of her friends, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher's only comment was, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says: "Interviewees who look as if they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to come across in the best possible way." Yet many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but wasn't even given an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what had happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression of a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian discovered that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and our words send different messages, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words agree with your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to appear too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job on the spot. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted to the offer with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss sensed how excited I was, he knew I wasn't going to turn him down. Consequently, he offered me a lower salary than I'd hoped for. I'm sure I could have got more had I managed to control my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests that it's a good idea to learn about the company before you go for an interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and convince others of your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests you have a few questions ready and avoid speaking in long, confused sentences. As she puts it, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was suddenly made redundant. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not in an office anymore, but I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. A career counsellor helped me, and I was the first to tell him, 'I don't want to go back to my old job.' Most people in their mid-forties need to work for money, but our children didn't need our support. We moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but our friendships have survived, and many visit us."

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that never happened. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss socializing with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the product."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to owners. To change careers, I needed qualifications, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control and have peace of mind now."

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I've always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics. My proudest moment was competing for my country and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because of the great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Serious surfers know the best waves are at dawn, so you can't party late at night. I miss sleeping in, but it's worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, especially if there's prize money. Winning the championship also got me a TV show about surfing, so I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in style, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters sometimes care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends who aren't in sailing. You can't focus on the sport all the time. I'm known in sailing, but I'm rarely recognized on the street, which I prefer. I get letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's amazing to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans. I enjoy being recognized when I'm out, but it can be difficult. My last girlfriend didn't like the attention I got from female fans, and we broke up because of my travel schedule. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in sports. I'm focused on my game now and will enjoy other things after I retire, which happens early in tennis.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't afford all this, and if I give in, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and arguments about health don't seem convincing compared to the attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with advertisers and having to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' that's still the effect they want."

A big stress for parents shopping with children is deciding which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads, so they don't ask for things she won't buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy treats, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on my mood. If I'm feeling good, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large eighteenth-century houses into this hotel. This allowed the hotel to install the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. The system records guest preferences, making their stay more comfortable.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests. At the Merrion, a high-tech system lets guests adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers will appreciate the technology in their rooms. MacCann expects 65% of the hotel's business to come from this market. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by installing extra cables and renting TVs, so they can be easily updated. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed.

Despite all this technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms are welcoming. The hotel also offers a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the Merrion must be excellent, as expected in luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular restaurant without financial risks.

With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to succeed.

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes thought skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was stylish and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically demanding.

For beginners, balance and control are very important, and you can only go faster as you get better. Your body position is crucial for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your body weight; this means leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It's fairly easy, isn't it? As you practice, you can slowly make your movements longer.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for a skater. Even the best professionals fall. To avoid injury, try to be as relaxed as possible when you fall. This reduces the shock of hitting the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can move on the ice confidently, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance, so you can quickly learn the basic moves and then the turns, jumps, and spins of elementary freestyle.

If you watch any good or professional skater, you will see how relaxed they are and how easily they move. To achieve this, you should regularly practice an exercise program. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include those for the legs, back, and shoulders, with special focus on the ankles and knees. After a long or intense session, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits heart and lung activity and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Bills**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can bring tears to your eyes. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder, 15**, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. There's no time for TV, going out with friends, or doing much besides gym and school. I try to take training one day at a time. When I'm very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

B. **Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. Some parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself. People say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was shy and hid behind me, but now she's met people worldwide and gained confidence."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I'd do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I do it for myself. My goal this year is to join the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

D. **Sarah's mother** says, "Sarah's passion for horses started at age 1. At 5, she got up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

E. **Jane McShane, 10**, is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When playing, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting a big head. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like embarrassment."

F. **Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game at 5. My father suggested it. He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to quit, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to put her down for being exceptional. If she has this gift, let her reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point because Chris, even at fourteen, was almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe grows by another centimetre. Every year, more very tall people are born. Interestingly, this does not mean we are creating a new super race. In fact, we are returning to what we were like as cavemen. We are losing the effects of generations of poor diet, with dramatic results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals (a lifestyle still followed by some hunter-gatherer tribes today). One study found that they based their diet on 85 different wild plants. Then about 9,000 years ago, farming was invented, with serious consequences. Most of the planet's green areas have been taken over by farmers, so just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has badly affected human health and body size. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay increased, as did diseases. Far from being a blessing, corn was a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, farming spread because a piece of farmed land could support ten times the number of people who had lived off it as hunter-gatherers. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by the world's wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets again reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. It is a welcome trend, though not without its own problems. Heights may have risen, but the world has not changed much. A standard bed-length has remained at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have shrunk rather than grown, while clothes manufacturers are constantly having to update their range of products. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some programmed upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, of University, it could be as much as 193 cm - and we are likely to reach it sometime this century. However, scientists add one note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller because of better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies are best at keeping in heat.) Since the climate warmed, we appear to have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when properly fed. And as the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even further. In other words, the growth of human beings could be offset by global warming.'

**Studio Audiences: What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made?**

Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV life, but they are still a mystery to many of us. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Among all live entertainment audiences, studio audiences are often seen as the least important. Some people in TV even treat them poorly, like one cameraman who said they are treated 'like cattle'. I thought studio audiences were just people wanting a bit of fame. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. TV tries to get different people for different shows.

Those of us who like watching TV at home don't understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in an uncomfortable studio to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. Why did she come? It was a chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was 'a friend gave me a ticket'.

Few of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, 'We always hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.'

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' What I missed was seeing live actors - from my seat, I only saw the back of someone's head. The opening scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio monitor. Going to a studio might be a bad way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most of the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I prefer places where people have left their mark. When I travel, I like visiting charming villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would cycle to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was my escape from school. I enjoyed exploring the hilltops, valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt both familiar and different to me, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a private diary, which was my first try at travel writing, a field in which I later became known.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it doesn't cost much more. The scenery isn't spectacular. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and along a canal. But I always look forward to when the train passes through back gardens. For a few moments, we can see people doing everyday things like making tea or doing the dishes. I see myself as a woman in a tiny train, looking into other people's homes. It's the ordinary landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer to find something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and full of rocks, so there are not many people. Some brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the sea's majesty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland through beautiful valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are few residents and visitors. It's an unknown, empty, and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found the area by chance as a student, and since then, I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he's growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favourite house in Britain. It was about finding peace and reconnecting with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the place of my dreams. It's a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys being around them. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a wonderful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals we found, and one night was enough to admire them and check our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard screams from my sons' bedroom: "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed in to find Domino the cat with Bianca, a white mouse I got as a Mother's Day gift, in his mouth. Domino ran around the room, avoiding the kids who were trying to stop him. I tripped and fell, and as I thought about how to stop Domino, I saw the snake escaping from its tank.

The room was chaotic with the cat, mouse, kids, and the snake all moving around. The dog was barking, and the pot boiled over in the kitchen. I turned off the gas and returned to the room. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and saved the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived to old age.

Feeling confident, I tried to catch the snake. It was difficult, but I sat on the floor and waited for it to calm down. Slowly, I lifted the snake and took it to the garden. I hoped it would go to the shed, but when I let go, it wrapped around my shoulders like a shawl. We stood there, my four children, me, and the snake. My eldest, DJ, said, "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."

We gently encouraged the snake to move on. It slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Write me a letter! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old art of letter writing might disappear. Yet, for me, getting a letter is special and different from any other way of communicating. There is the excitement when it arrives, the pleasure of seeing who it is from, and the enjoyment of reading it. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. My mother also made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Sometimes my father would write, and it was always a joy to get his long, funny letters. Most letters from home were about everyday events with my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but I remember the letters most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. When I was young, I often had boyfriends who had to work or study far away, and we could only stay in touch by writing letters. But instead of hurting the relationships, letter writing seemed to make them better. I found that I could often express myself more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's much better to have a year's worth of news! And it's even better when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters come from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked her for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would have missed out. As it is, we now write to each other regularly. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success, however, came this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was amazed that a correspondence could last so long. The local newspaper even thought it was worth reporting on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother before me, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends of their own in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become another 'lost art'. '

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art**

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists and researchers are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they might not last for future generations. The mountain, once a place for prayer and worship, has 4,000-year-old drawings on bare rock. These include pictures of cows with horns, fields, and various gods and goddesses. But as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues like this, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and the artwork. Some visitors even break off parts to take home as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good photo, they rub the drawings to see them better," he said. "The drawings are polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look clearer."

Other researchers say people come with long sticks with sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. But experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a 'no-go' area, allowing the public only on guided tours. Otherwise, he says, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.

Clottes disagrees. "Henry de Lumley's idea is the most severe, and while it is the most effective, it will also cause protests from local people," he said. "The site was classified as a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do as much as possible to save what is there."

David Lavergne, the regional architect, also wants to avoid closing the site. "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal," he said. "Our department thinks the best solution is to let people see the site, but because the area is very big, it is hard to stop visitors from damaging it. I would prefer that everyone could see it, but the main problem is money. We do not have enough funds to hire the necessary number of guards. We may have to consider charging a fee. There seems to be no chance of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who also worked on researching the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—tourists can now avoid the three-and-a-half-hour walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She thinks the only solution is to rope off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she said. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we don't take steps, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't afford all this stuff, and if I agree to their demands, I feel guilty about buying and feeding them unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset even before we leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising directly to children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and arguments about how bad sugar is for teeth are not convincing compared to the attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with advertisers and having to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb points out, "The purpose of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' the goal is still the same."

A big stress for parents shopping with children is deciding which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and advertisements, so they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for our son because they're bad for him, while we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy treats, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm in a good mood, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. Although parents might spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.

**Going up the wall**

In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, you can have a challenging climb anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd is silent. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more famous for the TV show Gladiators, but both the show and the climbing championships have one thing in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new and fast-developing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were many good climbing spots. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. Since cliffs were unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.

Soon, many sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges to hold onto. Many of these early walls were inspired by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher. In the mid-1960s, he built a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University. Robinson had the idea of setting natural rock in concrete blocks, which could be part of a wall. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s, but they had design problems. Walls could only be vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and angled slabs. Another problem was that once the walls were built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers would get bored with the same holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny developed a material that he shaped into forms like those on cliffs. These could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a new challenge. French manufacturers also started using panels on a steel framework. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere as free-standing structures. A system of interchangeable fixtures gave climbers endless new holds.

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky' very quickly. Acting is indeed a risky career. There are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, but others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it is your personal choice, and only you can be responsible for achieving your dream. There are no easy ways to become an actor - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after training you will succeed. It's about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new faces and talent, and there is always the chance of excitement, glamour, and sometimes big rewards. People often ask what talent is. I think it is natural skill plus imagination, which is hard to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. Why do people want to act? It is hard to explain why you want to act. In the theatre, the important thing is the moment of connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is central to all acting and motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might just shrug. They know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they take nothing for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and their fame might not last. Disappointment is the biggest enemy of an actor. Last month you might have been out of work, selling clothes or waitressing. Suddenly you get an audition, but even if you want the job, you might not get it. So actors often don't talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of competing for a role and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, the chance of rejection is there from the first moment you start auditioning. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, it's up to you, because if you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of top cookbook titles now available.

**A. Delia Smith**

When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes. Recently updated, it remains the go-to cookbook for many.

**B. Raymond Blanc**

Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, *Blanc Mange*, accompanies his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by explaining how and why ingredients work together. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 recipes and explains why some dishes might fail, using basic food chemistry. Raymond loves to entertain with his cooking, and this book shows how skilled he is.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**

Le Cordon Bleu is known for the best in classical French cooking. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, the school released the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, featuring 100 respected recipes. While the recipes are classic, they are still fresh and have been updated to be healthier. The book starts with kitchen basics and includes sections on Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have shared their famous recipes and secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**

Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, challenges the idea that good food takes a long time to prepare. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This book includes over 200 recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Written in his fun and enjoyable style, Nigel proves that fast food can also be great food. If you doubt it, try his recipes—they're simply delicious.

Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have shrunk rather than grown, while clothes manufacturers are constantly having to update their range of products. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some programmed upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, of University, it could be as much as 193 cm - and we are likely to reach it sometime this century. However, scientists add one note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller because of better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies are best at keeping in heat.) Since the climate warmed, we seem to have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when properly fed. And as the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even further. In other words, the growth of human beings could be offset by global warming.'

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was suddenly made redundant. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counsellor I spoke to was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work immediately for money. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left our friends, but our friendships have survived, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible.
