Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I decided to help more women try running, to show them how fun it can be and to give them the confidence to start. I started a running club for women in my area because I was upset with many race organizers. They complain about the lack of women in the sport but use this as an excuse not to provide separate changing rooms. I put up posters, and 40 women, both young and old, fit and unfit, joined. They were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had really thought about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined hard training. They didn't think about chatting and smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they ran for only a minute - now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about diet and staying fit in general. I wanted to do something for women's running, and I've enjoyed watching their progress - almost as much as they have.'

Title: The History of the Iditarod - The Last Great Race on Earth

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there hoping to become rich. New towns were built quickly. One of these towns was called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During the summer, boats could bring supplies to these towns, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making travel impossible. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to cross Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could rest and eat, and feed their dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams for transport.

However, in 1925, the dogs were needed again when a disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, Carl Eielson, the only pilot skilled enough for the flight, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide him through the snow, and Togo proved to be a good guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to go further, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there if you want. The bar is also made of ice, so putting hot drinks on it is not a good idea! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothes are also available. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in the summer and is rebuilt each winter. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Text: 'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football in an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' The story appeared in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who had helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her playing football outside the club. He noticed she was very fast. 'He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot.' But Jose visited her parents and convinced them she could be successful and this would help their poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had refused before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She explains, 'They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.'

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You must wear special covers on your shoes to avoid scratching the glass. Walking on the Skywalk makes you feel like a bird flying high in the air.

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest and are only a few hundred miles from the center in more southern areas. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as amazing. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You start from Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. This city is located between the ocean and the mountains, allowing its residents to ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains a day would leave Vancouver on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey is still a great adventure. You sleep on the train, which is fun, but you travel through some of the best scenery at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago, when the rulers of China opened a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many early zoos, animals were trained to perform for visitors. This does not happen anymore, and now zoos are places where people can see animals acting naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with zoos. People who support zoos say they give us a chance to learn about nature and be close to wild animals, which would not be possible without zoos. On the other hand, some people are against zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played on stage! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to play in it gets accepted—only about half do. But anyone who is eager to play goes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country—I’ve been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. But I find it exciting because it's both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music, but you also feel you're part of its history, as you're playing on stage like great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who have supported us all the way. Without them, we wouldn't get anywhere with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert It can rain anytime between November and March in Marrakesh, Morocco. It doesn't happen often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning the streets into rivers. However, since many winters have been dry recently, the rain is welcomed by the local people. Marrakesh's parks and gardens exist not because of the rain, but thanks to a network of underground channels, dug in the 11th century, which bring water from the mountains all year round. Dry places that get water this way are called oases. Further south from Marrakesh, travelers reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by the water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow in winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has older brothers who work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try to find full-time jobs in a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus during the summer and go back home for the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8-18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to big newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites. If newspapers or TV and radio stations accept our stories, you can read or listen to them on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers where young people can meet and join projects, and we plan to open more centers across the country. Our agency started in 1994, and we were first called 'Young News'. Since then, over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities they had. Age wasn't important; they were trusted to do the stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll get training and join monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff on these trips. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training is in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, Antarctica Sightseeing Flights takes tourists in a large passenger plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to another date if we need to change the flight day.

**Questions**

These are answers to common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.

**How long is the flight?**

The flight usually lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we start seeing the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time flying back. On the way to and from Antarctica, experts who have lived at research stations there give talks about the environment and history, and answer questions. A camera near the pilot, connected to the video system on board, shows you the pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, passengers switch to the seat on their second boarding pass. Business and first class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to walk around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting spots so both sides of the plane can see the sights well.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different approved flight routes. Our captain checks the satellite cloud images on the morning of the flight and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land on Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. To see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes! All cameras are welcome. We even offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble preparing onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends which they really enjoyed. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous because it's hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog might be waiting for you over a hill. Ice could be hiding under melting snow, ready to make you slide off the road. The car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, when you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive so you wouldn't spill it. Rule Number Two is to pay attention to what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law, but instead, he went to art school. There, he found traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued painting. In his late twenties, he received money from the Italian government to study art. He became interested in early Italian artists, which is visible in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian fields and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. This led him to paint colors thinly, one on top of another, from light to dark. However, he says he's never sure what the results will be. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he never makes drawings before starting a painting, as he feels that if he did, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why his favorite models are people who don't ask to see their pictures while he's painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he has not felt part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but just paints the way he can. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we were against the idea because of the noise. 'It's better than watching television or playing computer games in my free time,' Ben argued, 'and it'll keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'All right,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbours when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are not easy to move, the other members of Ben's band started coming to our home with their guitars and other electrical equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practising, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must admit that, although their music may sound a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill - after all, I didn't expect my parents' generation to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their school work because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives young people important experiences outside the classroom, as well as the chance to study for their exams. The students, who are between 16 and 18 years old and come from all over the world, study in the morning. In the afternoon, they do useful activities like helping on a farm, taking care of people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different countries and social backgrounds. Since not many can pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, there are grants available. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get help from the government.

"I really admire the college for trying to encourage international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn't believe how much less I argued with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College gives its students an excellent education, using methods that really seem to work.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly, and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a good amount of money, but I was bored because I didn't have to think much. I felt stuck in the job and became unhappy. I was jealous of the students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope, and I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I'm a student, I find it hard to mix with younger classmates. They often think I am a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel different from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am happy to study because I know you need a qualification to get a good job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending a weekend with my books rather than going out to party. There are also benefits like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I often wonder what I'll do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age has been a good decision.'

Text: 'Henry Ford Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not like farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. By using strong but light steel, he made cheap cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he built the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. He soon sold 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant less choice. 'You can have any color you like,' said Henry Ford of the Model T, 'as long as it's black.' '

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs £150. If you prefer to start in June, we have another course that lasts 10 weeks and costs £200. I hope this is the information you need. Yours, David May '

Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before she climbed the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and her family and traveled to Asia with some other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is difficult. 'You have to carry everything on your back,' she explained, 'so you can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!' When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now she has written a book about the trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She has a new job too, on a science program on television. Rebecca is well known today and she has more money, but she still lives in the small apartment in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!'

Dear Mike, I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a great party; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some nice presents. I'll tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are large blue and white birds. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to where it is warmer. The winters in Canada are so cold that the birds would die if they stayed. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn.' Bill had a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When the cold weather came in autumn, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, Bill was waiting for the birds to come back. They didn't arrive, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends decided to go to college, but Esther used her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and some glass jars and began making her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon doubled her aunt's £500. At first, her parents didn't want Esther to spend her time making jam and thought she should study instead. They hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor one day. But Esther didn't listen to them. She kept making jam. After a few months, she started selling it at the local market. Then she began making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked. After two years, her business was very large, and her parents were very happy with her. She made all kinds of food, which she sold to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she had to hire some people to work for her.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to come to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I am very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you invite Karen to go? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline '

Corryvale Farm Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. But most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each one has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool off the sheep so they don't get too warm. Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters with the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. But it was summer, and the weather was hot, so people didn't want to buy sweaters. She then made some socks. Everyone loved them because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. That's how Jenny's business started. At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers, so she had to send the wool to a factory, where all the socks are now made by machines. There are six colours, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a favourite present. On the walls of Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers all over the world.

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like our teacher very much. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that the number of house burglaries has increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also said that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave a door or a window open. He reported that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home then. But he said that winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark and they can't be seen easily. Also, many houses are empty at that time because people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This will help to keep burglars away. He also asked neighbours to watch the other houses in the street when people are not at home. They should call the police if they see anything strange. 'We will also tell you how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of help costs nothing.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I'm writing to say thank you for the two nights I stayed in your lovely home. It was nice to see you again. Here are the photographs of your children that you asked for. They're good photos, aren't they? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera. I am going to visit my sister in New York next week. I will take a lot of photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time.

Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before people started farming, they went to the forest to find plants or fruit they could eat. This meant that people were always moving to find food. But about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and their villages slowly became bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers grew food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was hard when the weather was bad, and then some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it travels thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.'

Text: 'WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years later, she got her current job as a manager. This is what she told us about her job: 'My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach air hostesses and help them with any problems. I also attend many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer and then talk with some of the air hostesses. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I like office work too. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I can do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and continue to travel.''

Text: 'Dear Maria, It's nice to be back home in my country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I would like to return to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even harder. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8.30 a.m. train to Cambridge on 10th May. It is a large blue bag, and my name is written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms. Johnson, I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6.30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson'

The Weather People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for people in different jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers spent a lot of time looking at the sky, animals, and flowers to try to understand the weather. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if there is a red sky in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. But for the last few months, they've spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who had trouble with reading. Kevin learns words more easily by seeing pictures and hearing information than by reading. His brother wanted to help. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make a computer game, and now it's ready to use. It's a speaking and picture game. For example, if you look at the word 'hat', there's a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their computer game, and it will soon be on sale around the world. Many schools are interested in buying it.'

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I can go home to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But I find it hard to sleep at night after a concert because my head is full of music. Sport is important. Before I had a car accident, I went to the sports centre for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. I can't do that now, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well. Also, I drink a lot of water because it's good for your health. I should have about eight glasses a day, but I don't always drink that much. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but there are other things I like doing too. In my free time, I just listen to music or watch TV. It's good for you to do nothing sometimes. I don't get tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now I eat lots of things like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

Text: 'Bollywood 'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, making it the biggest film industry in the world. Most Indians prefer watching films to any other free-time activity, and ten million of them go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films usually tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of every film. Indian films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they do not earn as much money. This is why most Bollywood films only cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood film is never made for less than $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan, who some people say is India's greatest actor, is different. He has been the star of more than 140 films during an acting career of almost 40 years.'

Text: 'Bill Bryson I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived there with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have lived in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the United States. I think they will be happier because they have lived in two countries. I like Britain and I want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so it won't be for another four years. I just went to England for six weeks to work on a radio program about the English language and to talk about the book I just wrote. Most writers don't like doing this; they don't like traveling around the country to sell their book. I don't mind it. I like visiting new places and meeting lots of people. It's very different from my life in the United States when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was good because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me and it was fun.'

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer arrived more recently. The name Giant is suitable because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, which needs to be cut often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers are from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep, and the police also use them because they are very intelligent. A Schnauzer is a nice family dog. It is friendly and very good with young children.'

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two big towns. 'It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops where we could buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.'

Text: 'Dear Keira, Thank you for your letter. I had my first day at my new school today. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms were. She is very nice, and I will visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time. I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I must go now because I have to do my homework. Hester'

Text: 'New books this month The Long Night This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for several years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia, where she works in a small hospital. One day a baby is very sick, so Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They have many problems on the way and ... Hard Work This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they do not have much money. Then one day a man dressed all in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop ... Hospital or Cinema? Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star ... What will Tina do?'

Text: 'The history of horse racing Horse racing has always been an important sport. It started in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago and was popular in Greek and Roman times. Modern horse racing began when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. At first, races were long and between two horses, but in the early 18th century, this changed. Races became shorter and had several horses competing. Today, horse racing is watched by more people than any other sport in the USA, except baseball. It is also very popular in other parts of the world.'

World traveler Nick Barlow loves his job. He is a British actor, and he travels around the world to make TV shows. "People welcome me everywhere I go, and when I get home, I remember all the wonderful things that happened in each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still a few trips he would like to make. "I'd love to visit South America and go back to Australia one day," he says. On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring the cameras and other equipment needed to make the show. Nick doesn't take many things for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always makes sure to pack some books. Nick's wife, Helen, doesn't mind him traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he returns, she likes to hear all his travel stories. But sometimes there are problems. When he was in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick heard that his wife was sick in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so happy when I heard she was better."

Parrots

You might have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in large groups, and because they like to eat fruit, they can sometimes be a problem for farmers. There are many different types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet, which they use for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds and can easily be taught to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows, where you can watch the birds do tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometres west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on lots of clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much more difficult to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he has done the right thing.'

John Pickering works in a park in a small town in central England. He cuts the grass and waters the flowers. But last week, he was in Tokyo, and many people in Japan watched him on TV. John is 35 years old and is the most popular singer in Japan right now. He went to Japan a few months ago to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A radio DJ heard his songs and played them on his show. Many young people called the radio station to ask for the songs to be played again. John uses the name Jon Otis when he sings in Japan. He plans to keep working in the park in England because he does not know how much money he will make from his music. He says, 'I must keep my job in the park. I still have to pay my bills!' The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, 'This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!'

Text: 'Memo To: All staff Subject: Holidays From: D Brown Date: 22.2.02 I am planning the holidays for next year. Please tell me when you would like to take your holiday. If possible, could you give me two options? Please give me your answer by the end of the month. Thank you. D Brown Memo To: D Brown Subject: Holidays From: J Green Date: 23.2.02 Could I take two weeks' holiday in July? I'd like to take the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks will be fine. Also, can I take three extra days in the first week of December? John'

Text: 'Line dancing Thousands of people in Britain have a new hobby -- line dancing. In almost every town, you can find clubs and classes for this activity. 'Line dancing is easy to learn. If you have two feet and can walk, then you can do it!' says Fiona Lever, a teacher. 'You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are both young and old people. The boys like it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!' When did line dancing begin? Most people think it started about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.'

Text: 'The Rhino There are five different types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have big, heavy bodies. Their skin is very hard and they have very little hair. The large body of the rhino stands on four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They usually walk very slowly, but they can run at 50 kilometers an hour. Rhinos are usually quiet and calm animals, and they only eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and may live to be 50 years old.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, there are policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London had no policemen at all. A few old men used to guard the city streets at night, and they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was starting to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people stayed in their homes as much as possible. In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to stop thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had become very big and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was started with 3000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are quite well paid, and for the few police officers who still ride horses, the pay is even better than for the others.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Would you like to join a camping trip this weekend? We will go to the forest in the school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. It is very cold at night, so you should bring warm clothes and wear strong shoes. If you want to come, please tell me today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks every August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from all over the world. They come for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are full of music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even see artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, you can watch over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets for these shows are quite cheap, and it is usually easier to see your favourite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so why not book your hotel now!'

Text: 'ICE-FISHING If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake turns to ice, and thousands of Canadian fishermen go there each weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice. Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. 'You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy,' he says. 'First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport and you can meet some nice people here!''

Text: 'From: Greg To: Anna Hi Anna, I'm not having a good week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team played much better than us! Then my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't come to stay with us during the holidays because he has a summer job. We can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister woke up late, so she took my bike to school! She didn't tell me she needed it. I'm really angry with her. I hope you have some good news! Write back today if you can. Greg '

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's A very famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Here, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, made wax figures of people. He opened a museum of these figures in Paris, and Marie helped him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was sent to prison. There, she had to make copies of the heads of famous people after they died, including Queen Marie Antoinette's. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802 she came to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.'

Text: 'BICYCLES The bicycle is an affordable and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive, and only rich people could buy one. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we have today. Later, when bicycles became cheaper, many people bought them. People started riding bicycles to work and in their free time. Today, people use cars more than bicycles because cars are much faster and you don't get wet when it rains. However, some people still prefer to cycle to work. They say there are too many cars in city centers and it's hard to find a place to park.'

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were only interested in the elephant show. We went to a large square with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their keepers and stood in front of a large white card. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started to paint on its own card. Sometimes, the keepers gave the elephants a new brush with paint and took the old one away. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants drew pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe what I was seeing! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest of these animals live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Text: 'Big Cats There are many different types of big cats. They are different in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest big cats. From head to tail, they can be 3.7 meters long. Most cats don't like water, but tigers often lie in water when it is hot! Lions are the only big cats that live in large family groups. Several lions may work together to hunt for food for the group. They usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily follow other animals. All big cats need good eyesight because they catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Text: 'Dear Mrs. Brian, I am sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month. I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I'm sorry to leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you again. Best wishes, Soraya'

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write and tell me when you are free and where I can meet you. Hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I got it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant near there. Do you like Italian food? I have to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I'm happy because last month I got a new job in the city centre. I am working in a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to get up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I like telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me. I'm wearing my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are only a few left. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when they run. Ostriches can run very fast, from 65 to 90 kilometers an hour, so it is very hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without water.'

Text: Victoria Jamieson from Britain started snowboarding when she was 20 years old. Now, at 23, she has won many competitions in snowboarding. We talked to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she began the sport. She said, "I've always liked sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding was a natural choice. It doesn't take long to learn, and you can become really good in a few months." We asked if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains. It's so beautiful. But free-riding, which is doing what you want when not in a competition, is the best thing for me." We asked what is important when learning. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet because, at first, you spend a lot of time falling down!"

Text: '23 Oak Avenue Manchester Dear Sir or Madam, I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights from September 15th to 17th. I would like a single room with a shower. I also need a telephone in my room. Could I have a quiet room on the ground floor, please? I will drive to the hotel. Is there a car park at the hotel? I will arrive at about 10.30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive. Thank you for your help. Yours faithfully, Mark Jones'

Mount Kilimanjaro

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed Kilimanjaro, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is considered the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers who attempt to climb Kilimanjaro reach the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and wet, but when climbers get to the top, they find ice and snow, and the temperature can be below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out of their homes at night. Otters are very good swimmers and can move in the water at more than 10 kilometers an hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, which allows them to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty, so many fish and insects died, and the otters couldn't find food. But today, there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.'

Text: 'Dear Deshini, I'm happy you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family. I'll send more next time I write. I hope you'll write to me soon. Tom'

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a very good teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then go back home to Greece. I like London a lot. We went to Regents Park by bus yesterday. It was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a movie with my brother and some of his friends. I'll write again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I am going to visit your country next month with two friends. We don't know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We would like to stay in the centre. Can you help us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the centre are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always made buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to keep beautiful things. Many people work together on a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures to show their ideas. Engineers make sure the building will be strong and safe. Then, the workers carefully build it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. But the building is beautiful from every side, not just from the top. There is also a famous roof on the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This interesting building looks like a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. On the road between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a picture of a very large man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the village next to him is called Cerne. Nobody really knows when the Cerne Giant was made, but people think it was a very long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you go on the first of May at sunrise, you will see people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run the 10,000 meters and maybe the 5,000 meters at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in big races. But she always laughed and smiled, and people in her city love her for this. Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, a very long road race. She won with the fastest time of the year for any British woman runner. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. But it's not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him and he can't catch up. Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. But she always rests from running on Sundays. 'I am with her all the time,' says Mike. 'Sometimes I say, "Are you sure you should be eating that?" It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost everything.'

Text: 'Piano players - when they were young Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began his first song. Oleg Gagarin Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he started lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly began winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years, then returned to Russia. Josef Heptmann Josef's father was German but taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he started playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef always liked music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now but hopes to write his own music one day.'

Bill Prince-Smith Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he started writing children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me when she doesn't like something,' says Bill. 'My ten grandchildren don't live nearby, but they also read my stories and tell me if they are good or bad.' This way, Bill has learned what young children like to read. Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His fifth book is his favorite: The Sheepdog is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. 'I have always liked animals,' says Bill, 'and dogs are so clever, they learn very quickly.' Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine and I love the film.'

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people like to send postcards to their friends and family. These postcards often have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles on them, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because postcards are cheap, and the pictures on them are often better than people's own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards had pictures showing something in the news that week, like an accident or an important person's visit. People liked to see them because they did not have pictures in their newspapers then.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaur died about 60 million years ago, long before there were any people on Earth. Nobody knows exactly why they all died. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. Dinosaurs didn't all look the same. There were more than 5000 types. Some were very small, but others were huge. The largest were bigger than any other animals that ever lived on land. The Brontosaurus, for example, was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was stronger. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because it had long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. Bears are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they cannot see well and, like most animals, they find food by using their noses. There are seven types of bears: The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: One lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. But not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Not many pandas live in the forest today because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm parts of the world, like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat anything they catch, such as fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are more than ten types of crocodiles. All of them have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. Crocodiles can live for a long time. The oldest one in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon that could carry people into the air. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first plane with an engine and flew it in the United States. Then, in 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, planes became much faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour, so the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by plane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round, there was no roof, and people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen loved going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to see the plays of William Shakespeare. All the actors at that time were men. The visitors ate, talked to their friends, walked around during the show, and some people even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or just learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is so warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different here: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
